Manuscript of "Missionary Travels and Researches in South Africa" (Part I).
David Livingstone

Date of composition: January-October 1857
Repository: National Library of Scotland, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Shelfmark: MS.42428
Clendennen & Cunningham number(s): Books, 001
Digital edition and date: Livingstone Online, 2014
Publisher: UCLA Digital Library, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Project id:
TEI encoding: Justin Livingstone, Adrian S. Wisnicki, Kate Simpson, Stephen Hall, Johanna Green, Peter Slater

1
The Right. Hon - Labouchere

                  Sir
5

                In case it should be
out of your power to grant me
more than a minute or two
in the interview to which you kindly
10invited me when I had
the honour to be introduced to you
in the House of Commons I now
beg leave to lay before you
in writing a subject to which
15I most earnestly beg your
attention as it seriously affects
the pros-perity of English commerce
and the honour of the English
name -


20

About half of our {the} Frontier
of the Cape Colony is occupied
by Independant tribes named
Griquas & Bechuanas - who
25have not only faithfully observed
the treaties made by the {f}
former Colonial Governments
during the last 30 years
but have never been
30even accused of cattle
stealing or the progress
of or annoyance to the [0002]
the Colonists English - SeveralMany hundreds
thousands of these people have
become Christians through the
teaching of English missionaries
5and have engaged in commerce -
so assidusously that about
£5000 of worth of ivory and
30 000 skins of small
animals are annually sent to
10the Colonial markets



            Their feeling of con
-findence in the English sense
of justice may be judged
15of by the fact that when
the Transvaal Boers
attacked the town of Sechele
a chief living 10° degrees
of Latitude from Cape
20Town and contrary to
the express provision in
an Article of the treaty which
these Boers had entered
into with Sir George
25Cathcart kidnapped about
200 of Sechele's children
whom I offered to identify
as members of Mrs Livingstone
school, This chief travelled
30through these ten degrees
one thousand miles in
order [   ] to beg the English
Queen to have the article
against slavery enforced [0003]
2
and his children restored to the
parents



5

When Sir George Cathcart
[gave] the Rebels Boers their
indepdendance he also passed
a Powder Ordinance by
which ammunition to any
10amount may be sent into
into the Transvaal Territory
while not an ounce can
be is allowed to enter the
country of the Griquas &
15Bechuanas - This I beg you
to observe has no reference
to the Caffres on our Eastern
Frontiers - It refers entirely
to the West, and as there
20is not a {t}he smallest doubt
that these Transvaal Boers
continue in the open violation
of the treaty to enslave the
natives the enforcement
25of the provisions of the
Powder Ordinance against
those who have always
been our Friends amounts
to unintentional but direct
30aid to Slavery



        So long as the Boers
retained the name of British
subjects the practice of
35buying & selling native

[0004]

I. 3 1


Introduction



My own inclination would
5lead me to say as little as possible
about myself, but several
friends in whose judgement
I have confidence have suggested
that as the reader likes to
10know something about the
author, a short account
of my origin and early life
would lend additional
interest to this book - Such
15is my excuse for the
following egotism, and if an
apology be necessary for
giving my genealogy I find
it in the fact that it is
20not very long and contains
only one event of which
I have reason to be proud -


My great grandfather fell
at the battle of Culloden fighting
25for our old line of kings
[and my] ˄ My grandfather was a
small farmer in Ulva, where
my father was born, ˄ It is one
of that cluster of the Hebrides
30thus described by Walter Scott
"And Ulva dark and Colonsay"
And all the group of islets gay
"That gaurd famed Staffa round" *


My grandfather who was
35
* Lord of the Isles - canto IV. [0005]
2 {4}
intimately aquainted with all the
traditionary tales which that
great poet has since made
5use of in the "Tales of a grandfather"
and other works, long before their
publication, I remember listening
to ˄ him with delight as a boy for his
memory was stored with a
10never ending stock of stories
many of which were wonder
-fully like those I have since
heard while sitting by the
African evening fires
15While my grandmother sung
gaelic songs some of which,
as she believed, had been
composed by captive islanders
while languishing hopelessly
20among the Turks


My grandfather could give
particulars of the lives of our
ancestors for six generations
of the family before him
25and the only point of the tradition
I feel proud of is this - one of
these poor hardy islanders
was reknowned in the district
for great wisdom and prudence
30and when on his death-bed, it is
related that he called all his
children around him and said,
"Now in my lifetime I have searched
most carefully through all the traditions
35I could find of our family, and
I never could discover that there
was a thei {ie}f among our forefathers [0006]
5
^ since made use of in the Ta {in}teresting "Tales
of a grandfather" and other works -
l {L}ong before their publication, I
5remember listening with delight as
a boy to the never ending stock of
stories with which his memory
was stored - (wonderfully like these
tales were to what I have ˄ since often
10heard while {en} sitting by the African
[evening] fires) - ; while my grandmother
sung songs in gaelic some of
which, she believed, had been
composed by languishing captive
15islanders captives among the
Turks - ⎰To my grandfather I look
as an authority for the authority {enticity}
of the tradition for the sake of which
principally I refer to the genealogy
20at all - His father fell fighting
at Culloden on the side of the Pretender
He had thus been guilty of treason
which had it only been successful
₰ would have been loyalty of the first
25water - He was recognized while
still alive on the battle field by
a person of the same clan who
had fouught on the opposite side
He had a handful of gold and
30had placed the hand to the
wound from which his heart's
blood welled out in order to
glue the coin together and enable
him should his life be spared
35to hide to conceal it from the
observation of the plunderers⎱

Hecker history of
Epidemics of Middle ages

(3 {6}
[If therefore any of you or any of your children should
take to dishonest ways it will not be because it runs
in our blood, it does not belong to you,] I leave this word with you. Be
honest - " [↪ If therefore in
the following
pages I fall into
any errors
I hope they
will be dealt ˄ with
as honest mistakes
and not as
indicating that
I have forgotten
our ancient
motto - ] This ˄ wasevent took place at a time
when the Highlanders [↪ according to
Macaulay] were much
5like the Cape Caffres {Kaffirs} and any
one ˄ it was said, could escape punishment
for theft by presenting a share
? of the plunder to his chieftain.
[↪ My ancestors] They were Roman Catholics and
10long afterwards they were made
Protestants by the laird coming
round with a man having a
yellow staff - The new religion
went long afterwards perhaps
15it does so still by the name of
"the religion of the yellow stick - "


˅/ My grandfather finding
⎰his farm in Ulva unable insufficient to
support a numerous family⎱
20removed to Blantyre works,
a large cotton manufactury on the
beautiful c {C}lyde above Glasgow
and his sons having had the
best educations the Hebrides
25afforded, were gladly recieved
as clerks by the proprietors,
Monteith & Co. My grandfather
highly esteemed for his unflinching
honesty was employed in the
30conveyance of large sums of
money from Glasgow to
the works and in old age was
according to the custom of that
company pensioned off so as [0009]
(4 {7}
to spend his declining years in
ease and comfort


My uncles all entered H.M.'s service
5during the last war either as
soldiers or sailors but my
₰ father ⎰the best of the lot⎱ remained
at home, and too conscientious
ever to become rich as a small
10tea dealer, by his kindliness of
manner and winning ways
made the heartstrings of his
children twine around him as
firmly as if he had possessed
15every worldy advantage to bestow -
He ˄ [During the
the last twenty
years of his
life he held
the office of
deacon of
an Independent
church in
Hamilton and] deserves my lasting
gratitude and homage for
presenting me from infancy
with a continuously consistent pious
20example such as ˄ that an episode of which is beautifully
and truthfully portrayed
in Burn's "cottar's saturday
night - " He died in February last
in peaceful hope of that mercy
25which we all expect through the
death of our Lord and Saviour
when I was on my way below
Zumbo, expecting no greater
pleasure in this country than
30sitting by our cottage fire
and telling him my travels -
I revere his memory -


My earliest recollection
of my mother was that so often
35seen among the Scottish poor [0010]
(5 {8}
of anxious striving to make ends
meet, and aboutat the age of ten
I was put into the factory in order
5 [as a "piecer"] ^ to aid by my earnings to lessen
her anxiety - With a part of my
first weeks wages I purchased
"Ruddiman's rudiments of Latin"
and pursued the study of that
10language for many years
afterwards with unabated
ardour at an evening school
It {which} met between the hours ^ of eight & ten
The dictionary part of my pursuits labours
15were {was} followed up till twelve ˄
[o'clock] or later, if my mother did not
interfere by jumping up and
snatching my books out of my
hands        I had to be back in
20the factory by six, and continue
my work with intervals for
breakfast and dinner till eight
oclock again - I read in this
way many of the classical authors
25and knew Virgil and Horace
better at sixteen than I do now -
Our schoolmaster (supported in
part by the company) was
kind and ˄ so moderate in his
30charges that all who wished for
education might have obtained
it - Many availed themselves
of the privelege and ˄some of my schoolfellows
now rank in positions far
35above what they appeared ever [0011]
(6 {9}
likely to come to in the village
school - If such a system were
established in England it would
5prove a never ending blessing
to the poor.


 

In reading I devoured [9a] [6*]
everything I could lay my hands
10on except novels - Scientific
works and books of travels
were my especial delight
though my father believing
that these with many of his
15time who ought to have known
better, that these were iniminical [0012]
(7 {10}
to religion, would have preferred
to have seen me at the "Cloud of
Witnesses or "Boston's fourfold
5state - "Ou {Our} difference of opinion
reached the point of open [ ]
rebellion and myhis last application
of the rod on ˄ my being desiredrefusal to
peruse "Wilberforce's practical
10christianity." The {is} dislike to
dry doctrinal reading ˄ & to religious [reading of every sort] continued
for years ˄ afterwards but having lighted
on those admirable works
of Dr Thomas Dick - "The philosophy
15of religion." and "The philosophy
of a future state" I was glad
to find my own ideas that
religion and science are
not hostile but friendly to each
20other ˄ [fully proved and
20enforced - ] and In the glow of love
which Christianity inspires I
[soon] resolved to devote my life to
the alleviation of human
misery - Turning this idea over
25in my mind I felt that to be
a pioneer for Christianity missionaries
in China would prove of
essential benefit to that immense
empire & therefore set myself
30to get a medical education in
order to fit myself for that
enterprise


In botany I had the guidance
of a book on the plants of
35Lanarkshire by "Patrick" which [0013]
(8 {11}
[in] recognizing the plants pointed out
in my first medical book that
extraodinary old work {Author} on
5astrological medicine - "Culpeper's
Herbal"        Limited as my time
was I found opportunities to
scour the whole countryside
"collecting simples" - Deep and
10and anxious were my studies
on the still deeper and more
perplexing profundities of
astrology amd I believe I
got as far into that abyss
15of phantasies as my author
said he dared ˄ revealto lead me - It
seemed perilous ground to
tread farther ˄ on for the dark hint
seemed to my youthful mind
20to loom towards "selling soul
and body to the devil" as the
price of the unfathomable
knowledge of the stars - {.} # These
excursions often in company
25with ˄ brothers, one now in Canada and
the other a clergyman in the
United States, gratified an {the}
intense love of nature I possessed
and opened up many a new
30idea and though we generally
returned mostso unmercifully
hungry and fatigued that the
embryo parson shed tears;
yet we discovered so many
35to us new and interesting [0014]
12 (9
things that he was always as
eager to join ^ us next time as he was
the last - # On one of these exploring
5tours we entered a limestone
quarry- long before geology was
so popular as it is now.
It is impossible to describe the
delight and wonder with which
10I began to collect the shells
of the carboniferous limestone
which crops out in high
Blantyre and Cambuslang .
and The quarrymen seeing
15a little boy ^ so engaged looked with that
pitying eye which the benevolent
assume when viewing the
insane . {-} I addressed ^ him with
"However did these shells come
20into these rocks"? "When God
made the rocks he made the
shells in them" was the damping
reply -        What a deal of trouble
geologists might have saved
25themselves by adopting the
Turco philosophy of this scotch
-man /


/ In my reading I could by
placing my book on a portion
30of the spinning jenny, catch sentence
after sentence as I passed at my
work, I thus kept up a pretty
constent study undisturbed by
the roar of the machinerys To
35this part of my education I owe [0015]
13 (10
I owe my present ability of completely
abstracting my mind from
surrounding noises, so as to
5read and write with perfect
comfort amidst the play of
children or near the dancing and
songs of savages - The toil of
cottonspinning to which I was
10promoted in my 19th year was
excessively severe on a slim
loose jointed lad, but it was
well paid and it enabled me
to support myself at the medical
15 [and Greek] [^] classes in Glasgow in winter
[as also the
Divinity lectures
of Dr Wardlaw] by while working with my hands
in summer , - I never recieved
a farthing of aid from any one
and would have accomplished
20my project of going to China
as a medical missionary
in the course of time ^ by my own efforts but some
of my friends advised my
joining the London Missionary
25Society on account of its
perfectly unsectarian character.
It "sends neither Episcopacy
nor Presbyterianism nor
Independancy, but the gospel
30of Christ to the heathen" This
exactly agreed with my ideas of
what a missionary society
ought to do - but it was not
without a pang I offered myself
35for I felt as if I should now [0016]
14 (11
become in a measure dependant
on others - And I would not
have been much put about
5though I had been rejected -
Looking back now on that
life of toil I cannot but feel
thankful that it formed such
a material part of my early
10education, and were it
possible I should like to begin
life ^ over again in the same lowly
style and pass through the
same hardy training - Our
15American cousins call the factory
life one of white slavery - i - e.
when they wish to descend to
that poor logic which always
shrivels up before the common
20sense proverb "two blacks dont
make a white" - Known in
Africa by the phrase "one fault
cannot wipe out another" -
I passed through every grade
25of factory labour from
the lowest to the highest and
the warmest sympathies of
my heart are {being} with the English
poor and Scottish poor I
30would denounce their any oppression
[↪ of them {in them}
if it existed] no matter by whom ^ practised - it is
⎰ [It is] ^ therefore with the fullest
conviction of truthfulness
I declare that anything like
35₰ ⎰American⎱ slavery does not exist
in English cotton factories⎱ [0017]
15 (12
I consider it in the highest
degree unfair to speak of those
as slaves whose blood boils
5at the thought of oppression -
and who glory in being the
sons of the Covenanters
and of them men who bled
at Bannockburn - Though
10we are the victims of great
social evils arising from
overpopulation - Those evils
are not to be mentioned
in the same breath with that
15slavery which is indissolubly
connected with the idea of
[outlawry &] bloodhounds -       There is no one
[here] ^ so degraded as not to be able
to claim his pay and though
20that rate is often far too low
no Englishman can be guilty
of the prime element of
slavery viz- the shabbiness
of expecting services from an
25inferior class without pay-
-ment. This meaness does not
exist on English soil -


/ The perfect freedom of
speech we enjoy in Britain
30and the fact that the man
who exposes domestic evils
in     the most startling terms
instead of being in jeopardy
for speaking out is lauded
35on all sides - leads strangers [0018]
16 (13
to the concluson that where
evils are most exposed they
most exist - My humble         
5belief tha is that in England
we have more true liberty with
and the greatest amount of
happiness for the greatest
possible number of any
10country in the world -


[The poorest] We ^ poor among us could stroll ^ at pleasure over the
ancient domains of Bothwell
and other spots hallowed by the
venerable associations [↪ of which even
our school
books made
us well
aware] and
15few of us could view th {such}
memorials of historythe past without
feeling that these carefully
kept monuments were
[our] their own - The masses
20 [of the working] ^ of the people ^ have read history
and are no revolutionary
levellers - We {They} rejoice in
the memories of "Wallace and
Bruce and 'a' the lave" they
25 [who are] still ^ the much lovedrevered as the former champions
of our freedom - and while
foreigners imagine we want
spirit to overturn our
[capitalists] and aristocracy we are content
30to respect our laws - till
[we can] we change them and hate
[those] stupid revolutions which
might sweep away time honoured
institutions dear alike to rich & (poor
35If slavery were attempted on {to} [be imposed on
35^ thesesuch people]
no human power could restrain their vengeance [0019]
17 (14
Having finished the medical
curriculum and presented
a thesis on a subject which
5required the use of the stethescope
for its diagnosis, I unwittingly
procured for myself an
examination rather more
severe and prolonged than
10usual among examining
bodies - The reason was
a difference of opinion ^ existed as
to whether this instrument
could do what I asserted
15However I was admitted
a licentiate of Faculty of
Physicians and Surgeons
but though qualified for
my original plan the
20opium was then raging
and it was deemed inexpedient
for me to proceed to China
I had previously pursued
theological studies both in
25Glasgow and in England
so I went to Africa to
spend the following sixteen
years of my life as a
medical man and missionary


30

The general instructions
I recieved from the Directors
of the Missionary Society
led me as soon as I reached
Kuruman or Lattakoo then
35their farthest inland station [0020]
18 (15
from the Cape to turn my
attention to the North Without
waiting longer at Kuruman
5than was necessary to recruit
the oxen now pretty well
tired by the long journey
from Algoa I proceeded
in company with another
10missionary to the Bakuena
country and found Sechele
with his tribe located at
Shokuan - I had a very different
object in view than running
15in three hundred miles and
back again as this journey
proved to be - Accordingly
after again resting three months
at Kuruman which is a sort
20of head station in the country I
returned to a spot about 15 miles
south of Shokuan called Lepelole
and (now Litubaruba) and in
order to obtain an accurate
25knowledge of the language, cut myself
off from European society for
about six months at once and
gained by the ordeal an insight into
the habits, ways of thinking laws
30and language [↪ of that section
30of the Bechuanas
30called Bakuena] which have proved
of incalculable advantage in my
intercourse with them ever
since

[0021]

19 (16
/ In my nextthis second journey to a spot about
20 miles south of Shokuan called
[to the place called] Lepelole from a cavern of that
5name, I began preparations
for a settlement by marking
a canal to irrigate gardens
from a stream then flowing
copiously - When preparations
10were well advanced we went
Northwards to visit the Bakaa
and Bamangwato and the
Makalaka living between 22° & 23
[south Lat-] This part {The Bakaa mountains} had been
15visited before by a trader who
with his people all perished
from fever - In going round
the Northern part of these Basaltic
hills near Letloche I was only
20ten days distant from the
lower part of the Zouga which
passed by the same name as
Lake Ngami, and I might then
(in 1842) have discovered that
25Lake had discovery alone been
my object - Most part of this
journey beyond Shokuan was
performed on foot , in consequence
of my waggon oxen having
30become sick - diseased, ill - ? Hearing my
companions discussing my
appearance & abilities on the
supposition that I did not
understand their speech - "He
35is not strong - He is quite slim" [0022]
20 (17
and only appears stout, because
he puts himself into those bags , {^} (trousers) He
will soon knock up - " my
5highland blood rose and made
me despise the fatigue of keeping
them all at the top of their speed
for days together and untill I
heard them expressing proper
10opinions of my pedestrian powers


Returning to Kuruman
in order to bring my luggage to
our proposed settlement I was
followed by the news that my
15friendly tribe of Bakuen had
been driven from Lepelole by
[the Barolongs] another tribe and my prospects
blasted - One of those periodical
outbreaks of war which seem
20to have occurred from time
immemorial for the sake of cattle
had burst forth in the land and
so changed the relations of the tribes
[to each other] I was obliged to set out anew
25to look for a proper locality for
a settlement -


In going North again a comet
blazed on our right exciting
the wonder of every tribe we
30visited - That of 1816 had been
followed by an irruption of the
Matibele the most cruel enemies
they ever knew and this might
portend something as bad, or
35it might be only the death of
some great chief - On the [0023]
21 (18
subject of comets I ^ then knew as
little as [↪ more than] they did themselves but
I had ^ that confidence in a kind over
5ruling Providence which makes
such a difference between us
and both the ancient and modern
heathen -        As some of the
Bamangwato people had
10accompanied me to Kuruman
I was obliged to restore them
and their goods of {to} their chief
Sekomi This made a journey
from Shokuan to that chief
15^ again necessary and I for the first
time performed a distance of
some hundred miles on oxback


Par //   / Returning ^ towards Kuruman again I selected the beautiful
valley of Mabotsa [↪ Lat deg {↪ Lat 25° 14' South
Long 26° 30'(?)}] to form a
20missionary station and thither
I remained with another missionary
in 1843. Here occured {happened} an episode
concerning which I have
frequently been questioned in
25England and which but for
the importunities of my friends
I meant to keep in store to tell
my children when in my dotage
The Bakhatla of the village
30Mabotsa were much troubled
by lions which leaped into
the cattle pens ^ by night and destroyed
their cows -       They even attacked
the herds in open day - this was
35so unusual the people believed [0024]
22 (19
that they were bewitched "given
[as they said] "into the power of the lions" - by
a neighbouring tribe - They went
5once to attack the animals but
being rather a cowardly people
compared to Bechuanas in
general on such occasions,
they returned without killing
10anyone - // If one in a partytroop of
lions is killed it is well
known the others take the
hint and leave that part
of the country - ˄ So the next time
15the herds were attacked I went
with the people in order to
encourage them to rid themselves
of the annoyance by destroying
one of the number - We found
20the lions on a small hill of
about a quarter of a mile
in length and covered with trees
A circle of men was formed
round it and they gradually
25closed up, ascending pretty close {near}
to each other - I being down below
- ? of what? on the plain with a native ^ teacherschoolmaster ^
a most excellent man, called
Mebalwe, saw one of the lions
30sitting on a piece of rock within
the now closed circle of men -
Mebalwe fired at it before I could
and the ball struck the rock on
which the animal was sitting
35He bit at the spot struck as a
dog does at a stick or stone [0025]
23 (20
thrown at him - The circle opened
and allowed him to escape - The
men were afraid perhaps on
5account of their belief in
witchcraft - Re=forming the
circle we saw other two lions
in it but the men allowed them
to burst through too {also}. If they
10had acted according to the
custom of the country they
would have speared them
in their attempt to get out -
Seeing it in vain to get them
15to kill one of the lions we bent
our footsteps towards the village
and in going round the end of
the hill I saw one of the beasts
sitting on a piece of rock as
20before but this time he had a little
bush in front - Being about
30 yards off I took a good aim
at his body, through the bush
and fired two both barrels into
25it - The men then called out
"he is shot" "he is shot - " Others cried
he has been shot by Matlatleanother too
Let us go to him." I did not see
any one else shoot at him, so
30I said "stop a little till I load again"
and when in the act of ramming
down the bullets I heard a shout,
starting round I saw himthe lion just
in the act of springing upon
35me - I was upon a little height [0026]
24 (21
he caught my shoulder in the
act of the spring and we both
came down to the plain ground
5below together - He shook me
as a terrier dog does a rat,
I turned round ^ to relieve mysef of the weight as he had one
paw on the back of my head
and saw him {his} eyes directed
10to Mebalwe who was trying
to shoot him at a distance
of 10 or 15 yards - His gun
missed being a flint one
missed fire in both barrels
15the lion left me and bit his
thigh - Another man whose life
I had saved ˄ before after he had been
tossed by a buffalo attempted
to spear the lion when he was
20biting Mebalwe - He left Mebalwe
caught this man by the shoulder
and then his woundsbullets took
effect for he fell down dead
The whole was done quickly
25and must have been his
paroxysm of dying rage - In
order to take out the charm from
him the Bakatla on the following
day made a huge bonfire
30over the carcase which was
declared to be that of the largest
lion they had ever seen - Besides
craunching the bone he left eleven
teeth wounds of the upper part
35of my arm - A wound from [0027]
25 (22
this animals tooth resembles a
gunshot wound - There is a
great deal of sloughing and
5discharge - and pains are
felt in the part periodically
ever afterwards - Having on
a tartan jacket on the occasion
I believe that wiped off any
10virus from the teeth that
pierced the flesh for my two
companions have both suffered
from the peculiar pains while
I have escaped with only the
15inconvenience of a false
joint in my limb - The man
whose shoulder was wounded
actually shewed me his wound
burst forth afresh on the
20same month of the following
year - This curious point deserves
the attention of enquirers -

[0028]

26 (23
The different Bechuana tribes
are named after certain animals
shewing probably that in former
5times they were addicted to
animal worship like the ancient
Egyptians - The Bakatla = they
of the monkey - Bakuena = they
of the alligator Batlaping = they
10of the fish - each tribe having
a superstitious dread of the animal
[by] which they areit is called - They also
use the word "bina" to dance
in reference to these custom
15so that when you wish to ascertain
what they are you say "what do you
dance" as if that had been a
part of the worship of old - They
never eat this animal using the
20term "ila" hate or dread in reference
to killing it and we find traces
of many ancient tribes in the
country in individual Batau
They of the lion - Banoga they of the
25serpent though no such
tribes now exist - The use of the
personal pronoun they - Ba - Ma
Wa - Va - or ova, Am. Ki &c. prevails
very extensively in the names of
30Par tribes in Africa - // I attached
myself to the tribe called Bakuena
or Bakwains the chief of which
is called Sechele ˄ was then living
˄ with his tribe at a place called {named} Chonuane
35I was from the first struck [0029]
27 (24
by his intelligence and the marked
manner in which he {we} both
felt drawn to each other rather
5than to others - and as this remarkable
man has not only embraced
Christianity but expounds its
doctrines to his people I shall {let me}
offer a brief sketch of his
10carreer


His great grandfather
Mochoasele was a great traveller
and the first that ever told of
the existence of white men - In his
15father's life time two white travellers
whom I suppose to have been
Mr Cowan and Dr Donovan
passed through the country and
passing down the Limpopo
20were all cut off by fever
The Rain makers fearing their
waggons might drive away
the rain ordered them to be
thrown into the river - This is the
25true account of the end of that
expedition - They were not killed
by the Bangwaketse as reported for
they passed the Bakwain, all well.
The Bakuena were then rich in
30cattle and as one of the many
evidences of the dessiccation of
the country streams are pointed out
where thousands and thousands of
cattle drank in which water never
35now flows and where a single herd
could not find fluid for its support

[0030]

II. 25 28
When Sechele was still a boy his father
was murdered by his own people for
making free with the wives of his
5rich underchiefs, The children being
spared, their friends invited Sebituane
then in those parts to reinstate them in
the chieftainship - Sebituane surrounded
their town of the Bakwena by night &
10just as it began to dawn his herald
proclaimed in a loud voice that he
had come to revenge the death of
Mochoasele - the pain this was
followed by ↪ a beating ^ loudly on their shields
15⎰of Sebituane's people⎱ all round the
town - The panic was tremendous
and the rush like that of a theatre on
fire while the Makololo used their
javelins on the terrified males as they
20 [with a dexterity they] alone can employ - Sebituane had
given orders to his men to spare
the sons of the chief and one of
them to {m}eeting Sechele put him in
ward by giving him such a crack
25with a club on the head as to
render him insensible, The usurper
was put to death and Sechele reinstated
in his chieftainship felt ^ much attached
to Sebituane - The influence here
30noticed it will ^ yet be seen led me
at last into the new well watered
country to which this same Sebituane
had preceded me - by many years -


Sechele married the daughters of
35three of his underchiefs who had
on account of their bloodrelationship [0031]
26 29
stood by him in his adversity - This is
one of the modes adopted for cementing
the allegiance of a tribe - the Government
5is patriarchal, each man being
by virtue of paternity chief of his
own children - They build their
huts around his and the greater
the number of children the more
10his importance increases - Hence
children are esteemed one of the
greatest blessings and are always
treated kindly - Near the centre of
each circle ^ of huts there is a spot called
15a "Kotla" with a fire place in
which they work, eat or sit and
gossip over the news of the day
A poor man attaches himself to the
Kotla of a rich one and is considered
20a child of the latter - An underchief
has a number of these circles
around his and the collection
of Kotlas around the great one
in the middle of the town whole
25or that of the chief constitutes the
town - The circle of huts immediately
around the Kotla of the chief is
composed of the wives huts of his
wives and those of his blood
30relations - He attaches the underchiefs
to himself and government by
marrying as Sechele did their
daughters or inducing his brothers
to do so. They are fond of the
35relationship to great families [0032]
27 30
If you meet a party of strangers and
the headman's relationship to some
uncle of a certain chief is not at once
5proclaimed by his attendants you
may hear him whispering "tell
him who I am - " This usually
involves a counting on the fingers
[of] a part of his genealogical tree ending [
by the important
fact that the
head of the party
is half cousin
to some well
known ruler]


10

Sechele was thus firmly seated
in his chieftainship when I made
his acquaintance, On the first
occasion in which I ever
attempted to hold a public religious
15service he remarked that it was
their custom when any new
subject was brought before them
to put questions on it - and he
begged me to allow him to do the same
20in this case, On expressing my
entire willingness to answer
him - He enquired if my forefathers
knew of a future judgment, I replied
in the affirmative and began to
25describe the scene of the "great white
throne and him who shall sit on
it from whose face the heaven
and earth shall flee away - " &c.
He said "You startle me - these words
30make all my bones to shake
I have no more strength in me - "
but my forefathers were living
at the same time yours were
and how is it they did not
35send word about these terrible
things sooner? They all passed [0033] 28 31
away into darkness without knowing whither
they were going - " I got out of the difficulty by
explaining the geographical barriers in the
North and the gradual spread of knowledge
5from the South to which we first had access
by means of ships, and expressed my belief
that as Christ had said it so the whole world
would yet be enlightened, Pointing to the great
Kalahari desert he said, you never can
10cross that country to the tribes beyond, it is utterly
impossible even for us black men except in
certain seasons when more than the usual
supply of rain falls and an extraordinary
growth of water melons follows - Even we
15who know the country would certainly perish
without them - Re-asserting my belief in the
words of Christ we parted and
it will be seen farther on that
Sechele himself assisted in
20crossing that Desert which had
proved an insurmountable barrier
to so many adventurers


/ As soon as he had an opportunity
of learning he set himsef to read
25with such close application was
that from being comparatively
thin the effect of having been
fond of the chase that he became
quite corpulent, Mr Oswel gave
30gave him his first lesson
[at figures] [^] and he acquired the alphabet
on the first day of my residence
[at Chonuane] with him - He was by no means
[an ordinary] a fair specimen of the people [0034]

for I never went into the town

Seeing me anxious that his people

these people will ever believe
by merely talking to them - I can
do nothing but by thrashing them
and if you like I shall call
15my headmen and with our

shall soon make them all

20on no other subject he would ask

25the space of two and a half years

on the subject he took that side
30acting at the same time in an

relations - He felt the difficulties
of his situation long before

35I wish you had come to this
country before I became [0035]
30 33
in the meshes of our customs"
In fact he could not get rid of his
superfluous wives without
5appearing to be ungrateful to

In the hoping that others
10would be induced to join him
in his attachment to Christianity
he asked me to begin with him
family worship with him in
his house. I did so and by &
15by was surprised to hear him
conduct the prayer in his
own simple and beautiful
style for he was quite a
master of his own vernacular
20We were suffering from the
effects of a drought which
will be described and none
except his family whom
he ordered to attend came near
25his meeting - "In former times"
said he "When a chief was
fond of hunting, all his people
got dogs and became fond
of hunting too: If fond of
30dancing or music all shewed
a liking to these amusements
too. If he loved beer they all
rejoiced in strong drink - But
in this case it is different,
35I love the word of God and not
one of my brethren will join me" [0036]
31 34
One reason why we had no
volunteer hypocrites was the
hunger ^ from drought which was associated
5in their minds with the presence
of Christian instruction and I
believe hypocrisy is not
prone to taking the line which
[seems to] ensure- empty stomachs


10

/ He continued to make

for about three years and

15the difficulties of his case

for the poor women who
were by far the best of our

20that he should be in any

wife too, was the {ab}out the

25the tribe ever to become

greasy disciple of the old school.
She has become greatly
altered, I hear, for the better
30since but again and again
'has {v}e' I seen Sechele send her

35picture of unutterable disgust at
his newfangled notions

[0037]

32 35
When he at last applied for baptism,
I simply asked him how he
having the bible in his hand
5and able to read it, thought he
ought to act - He went home
gave each of his superfluous
wives new clothing and all
his own goods which they
10had been accustomed to
keep in their huts for him,
and sent them to their parents
with an intimation that he
had no fault to find with
15them, but that in parting with
them he wished to follow
the will of God - On the day
in which he and his children
were baptized great numbers
20came to see the ceremony
Some thought from a stupid
calumny circulated by enemies
to Christianity in the south that
they would be made to drink
25an infusion of "dead's men's
brains" and were astonished
to find it water only - Seeing
several of the old men actually
in tears during the service
30I asked them afterwards the cause
of their weeping - they were crying
"to see," as the Scotch remark over
a case of suicide, to see their
father so far left to himself"
35They seemed to think I had
thrown the glamour over him
and he had become mine [0038]
33 36

5of these castaway wives

20it will yet spring forth though

/

        Leaving this sketch of the chief we
now proceed to give an equally rapid
5sketch of our dealing with this people ↪ of [↪ the Bakuena
5or Bakwains]
A small piece of land sufficient for a

went to live
with them]
though that was scarcely necessary
in a country when the idea
10of buying land was quite new.
It was expected that a request
[for a] suitable spot would have been
made and occupation follow,
as in the case of any other
15member of the tribe - But on
explaining that we wished
to avoid any cause of dispute
when land had become more
valuable or when a foolish
20chief began to reign and
we had erected buildings
of value he might wish to
claim the whole. About £5
of goods were given and
25the stipulation made that
a similar garden should be

at any other place to which
which the tribe might remove
30The particulars of the sale
sounded as strangely as
in the ears of the tribe as did
the [↪ a certain Roman] Emperor's tax [↪ in the ears of
his son and] on wine in

35the coin in either case emitted
no bad efluvium

[0041]

III. 35 38
In our relations with this
people we were simply strangers
exercising no authority or
5control whatever - Our
influence depended entirely
on persuasion, and having
taught them by kind conversation
as well as by public instruction
10I expected them to do what their
own sense of right and wrong
dictated - We never wished
them to do right ^ merely because it
would be pleasing to us
15nor thought ourselves to
blame when they did wrong -
although we were quite aware
of the absurd colonial idea
to that effect we believed that
20we saw that our teaching did
good to the general mind of
the people [↪ I am certain
of five cases
in which by
good influence
on public opinion
war was
prevented - ] and where in
individual cases we failed
they were no worse than they
25were before we came - , In general
they are slow like our African
people hereafter to be described
in coming to a decision on
religious matters, but in
30matters affecting their worldly
affairs they are keenly alive
to their own interests - They
might be called stupid in matters
which have not come under
35the sphere of their observation [0042]
36 39
but in all matters which have
they shew more intelligence than
is to be met with in our own
5peasantry - They are remarkably
accurate in their knowledge
of cattle, sheep and frogs goats -
Knowl {in}g exactly the kind of
pasturage suited to each, and
10they select with great judgement
the kinds of soil best suited
to different kinds of grain
They are adepts in knowledge
of the habits of wild animals


15

The place where we first
settled with the Bakwena is called
Chonuane, and it happened to
be visited ^ during the first year of our
residence there by one of those
20periodical droughts which occur
in even the most favoured
districts of Africa


[                ]
[0043]

37 40
there - Now the belief in rain making
is one of the most deeply rooted
articles of faith in this country -
5The chief Sechele being himself a
noted rain doctor believed in it
[↪ implicitly implicitly,] utterly - and he has often assured me
that he found it more difficult
to give up his faith in that, in than in
10anything else require by Christianity -
I pointed out the only feasible
way of watering the gardens to be
to select some good never
failing river - make a canal
15and irrigate their lands - This
suggestion was immediately adopted
and soon the whole tribe was
on the move to Kolobeng about
40 miles distant - The experiment
20succeeded admirably during the first
year - The Bakwains made the canal
and dam in exchange for my
labour in assisting to build a
square house for their chief - They
25also built their own school under
my superintendance - Our own house
at Kolobeng was the third which
I had reared with my own hands
but I had then become a jack of all
30trades - A native smith taught me
? iron to weld and having improved by
scraps of information in that line
and in capentering and gardening
and as my wife could make
35candles soap and clothes we [0044]
38 41
came nearly up to what may be
considered an {the} essential part of an
Central African missionary's
5qualifications accomplishments viz. the husband
to being a jack of all trades without
and the wife a maid of all work
within - But in our second
year no rain again - In the third
10the same extraordinary drought
followed - Indeed not ten inches
of water fell during these two years
and the Kolobeng ran dry, so many
fish being killed the hyaenas of
15the whole country collected to
the feast and were unable to
finish the putrid masses - A
large old alligator which had never
been known by any depredations
20was among the victims - The
fourth year was equally unpromising
unpropitious - Too little rain
to bring the grain to maturity, Nothing
could be more tantalising , We
25 [dug] digged down in the bed of the river
deeper and deeper as the water
receded, striving to get a little to
keep the fruit trees alive for
better times, but in vain, needles
30lying out of doors for months
did not rust, and a mixture
of sulphuric acid and water
used in a galvanic battery
parted with all its water to the
35air instead of imbibing more [0045]
(39 42
as it would have done in England -
The leaves of indig⁽i⁾nous trees
were all drooping, soft, & shrivelled
5though not dead - And those of
the Mimosae were closed at midday
as they are when going to sleep -
In the midst of this dreary
drought it was wonderful to see
10these wonderful tiny creatures the
ants running about with their
accustomed vivacity - I put the bulb
of ^ a thermometer 3 inches under the soil
and found itthe mercury to stand at 132˚ - 134˚
15and if certain kinds of beetles were
placed on the surface they ran
about a few seconds & expired -
but this broiling heat only augmented
the activity of the long legged black
20ant - They never tire - Their organs
of motion seem endowed with the
same power as is ascribed by
Physiologists to the ^ muscles of the human heart
by which that part of the frame
25never becomes fatigued and
which may be imparted to all
our bodily organs in that higher
state to which we fondly hope to
rise - Where do they get their
30moisture - ? Our house was built
on a hard ferruginous conglomerate
in order to be out of their way
^ of the white ant but they came in spite of
the precaution and not only
35were they in this sultry weather [0046]
40 43
able individually to moisten soil
to the consistency of plaster for
the formation of galleries towards
5any vegetable matter they might
wish to devour, but when their
inner chambers were laid open
they were these were also surprising
-ly moist humid - Yet there was
10no dew and the house being
placed on a rock they could
have no subterranean passage
to the bed of the river about 300
yards distant below the hill *


15

/ Rain however would not
fall - The Bakwains believed that
I had bound Sechele with some
sort of magic spell - And I recieved
deputations in the evening from
20of the old counsellors entreating me
to allow him to make ^ only a few showers
"the corn will die if you refuse, and
we shall become scattered" - "Only
let him this once and we shall
25come to the school and ^ sing & pray as
long as you like {please}" It was in
vain to protest that I wished Sechele
to act just according to his own
ideas of what was right as he found
30the law laid down in the Bible -
And it was distressing to appear
hardhard hearted to them - The clouds
 
 
*When we come to Angola I shall describe
35an insect there which distills several
pints of water every night [0047]
41 44
often collected beautifully over us, and
Rolling thunder seemed to portend

5the sun would rise in a cloudless

by far than days of sunshine are in
London -
⎰But how could they be so stupid
10as to suppose that only one could
make rain? Why there is first of

25Charcoal made of burned bats

and knowing that civility is

you think you {they} are mistaken,
10as to their power, the rain
doctor selects a bulb - {,} pounds it
and administers a cold infusion
to a sheep which in five minutes
afterwards expires in convulsions -
15Part of the same bulb is converted
into smoke which ascends
to the sky, rain follows in
a day or two - The case is clear
⎰Were we as much harassed by
20droughts, the logic would be
irresistible in England in 1857 -
The same looseness of reasoning

Qy JM the powers of the Homoeopathic
25globule? A powerful medicine
capable of appreciable effects is
manipulated into a decimal
fraction of moonshine ^ & post quod the cure
follows - The inference is irresistible⎱
30and why should not the discovers
share in the persecution which
Jenner, and Harvey &c. endured
They certainly deserve it seeing
opposition is the only point
35of similarity between our friends

[0049]

43 46
X As the Bakwains believed that there
must be some connection with the
between the presence of "God's word"
5in their town and these successive
and distressing droughts, they
looked with no good will at
the church-bell - but ^ still they invariably
treated us with kindness and
10respect - I am not aware of
ever having had an enemy
in the tribe - The only cause of
dislike was in the gospel -
expressed by a very influential
15and sensible man the uncle
of Sechele - "We like you as well
as if you had been born among
us, you are the only white man
we can become familiar with" (thoaela)
20⎰but we wish you to give up that
everlasting preaching and praying⎱
We cannot become accustomed
to that at all" "You see we never
get rain while those tribes who
25never pray as we do get abundance"
This was a fact, and we often
saw it raining on the hills 10 miles
off while it would not look at us
"even with one eye" - If the Prince
30of the power of the Air had
no hand in schorching us up
I fear I often felt uncharitably
towards his majesty -


As for the Rain makers they
35carried the sympathies of the [0050]

people along with them and not

10

Rain doctor - Very true my friend
and I ought for the whole country

M. D. So you really believe that
you can command the clouds
15I think that can be done by God

R. D. We both believe the very

the rain but I pray to him
20by means of these medicines
and of course the rain is mine -
It was I who made it for the
Bakwains for many years
when they were at Shokwane ,
25Through my wisdom their
women become fat and shining
Ask them they will tell you the
same as I do -


M. D. But we are distinctly
30told in the parting words of our
saviour that we can pray to
God acceptably in his name
alone and not by means
of medicines


35

/ R. D. Truly, but God told us
₰ differently - He made black [0051]
45 48
men first - and did not love us
as he did the white men - He
made you beautiful - and gave you
5clothing and guns and horses
and gunpowder and waggons
and many other things about
which we know nothing
But to^ward us he had no heart
10He gave us nothing except the

not give us hearts like yours
We never love each other [↪ other tribes put

must dissolve

by which we can make rain

20which you possess though
we are ignorant of them,

M. D. But {I dont} despise
what I am ignorant of I only

/ R. D. Thats just the way

46 49
making rain - and we follow

may do without rain, we
cannot manage in that way -
If we had no rain the cattle
would have no pastures, the
10cows give no milk - our
children become lean and
die - Our wives run away
to other tribes who do make
rain, and have corn, and
15the whole tribe become dispersed
and lost - Our fire would go out -


M. D.        I quite agree with you
as to the value of the rain, but
you cant charm the clouds by
20medicines - You wait till you
see the clouds come then use
your medicines and take the
credit which belongs to God only -


R. D. I use my medicines
25and you employ yours, we are
both doctors, and doctors are
not deceivers, you give a patient
medicine, sometimes God is pleased
to heal him by means of your
30medicine sometimes not - he
dies - When he is cured you take
the credit of what God does - I do
the same - Sometimes God grants
us rain sometimes not - In each
35case we take the credit of the cure - [0053]
47 50
When a patient dies you dont
give up trust in your medicine
neither do I when rain fails,
5If you wish me to leave off
my medicines why continue
yours?


M. D. I wish you would
try and God would give us
10rain without your medicines


R. D. [↪ Mahalama
-kapa,a,a-] Well I always thought
white men were wise till this
morning - Who ever thought of
making trial of [      ] starvation
15Is death pleasant then?


M. D. Could you make rain on
one spot and not on another


R. D. I wouldnt think of trying
I like to see the whole country
20green and all the people glad,
the women clapping their hands
and giving me their ornaments
for thankfulness - and lullibooing for joy


M. D. I think you decieve
25both thems and your-self -


/ R. D. Well there is a pair
of us - - (meaning both are rogues
exit M. D. mentally writing Cont. Med.)
The above is only a specimen
30of their way of reasoning in
which when the language is
well understood they are seenpercieved to
be remarkably acute - These arguments
are generally known and I
35never succeeded in convincing [0054]
48 51
a single individual of their fallacy
though I tried them in every
way I could think of - Their faith
5in medicines as charms is
unbounded - The general effect
of argument is to produce the
impression that you do not
feel anxious for rain at all
10and it is very undesirable to allow
the idea to spread that you do not
feel a generous interest in their
welfare - An angry opponent
⎰of rainmaking in a tribe
15would be like a Greek merchant
in England during the Russian war - ⎱


↪ [? The Conduct] The appearance of the people
during this long continued drought
was remarkably good - The women
20parted with most of their ornaments
to purchase corn from more
fortunate tribes - The children
scoured the country in search
of the numerous bulbs and
25roots which can sustain life,
and the men engaged in
hunting - Very large numbers
of the large game - buffaloes, zebras
giraffes, tsessebes, kamas, gnus
30pallas, Rhinoceroses &c. congregated
at some fountains near Kolobeng
and ^ the trap called hopos were {was} constructed in
the lands ajacent adjacent for their destruction
The Hopo consists of two hedges
35in the form of the letter V V. very [0055]
49 52
high and thick near the angle at
the bottom and at the extremity
of that same angle a deep pit
5is formed six or eight feet deep
and about ten in breadth & length
The Trees are laid accross the edge
over which the animals are
expected to leap and attempt to
10escape so as to form an over
lapping ledge which they cannot
possibly climb - As the hedges
are frequently a mile long and
about as much apart at their
15extremities tribe making a circle
extending three or four miles
round the country ajacent to the
opening and gradually closing
up are almost sure to enclose
20a large body of game - Driving
it up with shouts to the narrow
part of the hopo men secreted
there through throw their javelins into
the affrighted herds and on they
25rush into the pit till that is full
of a living mass - Some escape
by rushing over the others as
a Smithfield market dog does
over the sheep ^ {s} s backs It is a frightful scene
30The men wild with excitement spear
the lovely animals with mad delight
Others borne down by the weight
of their dead & dying companions
every now and then make the
35whole mass heave in their smothering [0056]
50 53
agonies - No one but a born butcher
could look on that scene without
feeling sick at heart - The Bakuena
5often killed between sixty and
seventy head of large game at
the different Hopos in a single
week and as every one both rich
and poor partook of the prey, the
10>meat counteracted the bad effects
of an exclusively vegetable diet -
When the poor who had no salt
were forced to live exclusively on
roots they were often troubled by
15with indigestion - Such cases
we had frequent opportunities of
seeing at other times for the district
being destitute of salt the rich alone
could afford to buy it - The native
20doctors aware of the cause of
the malady usually prescribed
some of ingredient with their
medicines - The doctors themselves
had none so the poor resorted to
25us for aid, We took the hint and
henceforth cured the disease by
giving a teaspoonful of salt minus
the medicines other remedies -
Either milk or meat had the same
30effect though not so rapidly as
the salt - Long afterwards when
I was myself deprived of salt
for four months at two distinct
periods I felt no desire for
35that condiment, but I was [0057]
51 54
plagued by very great longing
for these articles of food
This continued as long as
5I was confined to an exclusively
vegetable diet - And when
I procured a meal of flesh
though boiled in perfectly fresh
rain water it tasted as
10pleasantly saltish as if slightly
impregnated with the condiment
Both milk and meat removed
                              (Turnover)
                                  ?

[0058]
IV. 62 55

entirely the excessive longing and

/ Had there been no other adverse

15frequent absence - for ^ the purpose of either hunting

Ragged schools would have been

25wisely provided food for the

30we can no more hope for healthy
feelings among the poor either

feeding ^ them into them than we can

/ Another adverse influence
10with which the mission had to
contend was the vicinity of the
Boers of the Cashan mountains
otherwise named "Magaliesberg" -
These are not to be confounded
15with the Cape Colonists who sometimes
pass by the name - The word simply
means "farmers" and is not
synonymous with our word
Boor, Indeed takingto them generally
20there term is inappropriate for
they are a sober, religious, industrious
and most hospitable ^ body of peasantry -

25pretexts, and have been joined

30The great objection many of them

35of their Hottentot slaves, and [0061]
65 58
determined to erect themselves into

pursue without molestation the
5"proper treatment of the blacks - "
without It is almost needless to
add that the "proper system" has
always contained ^ in it the essential
element of slavery viz. compulsory
10 [unpaid] labour without payment -
One section of this body under
Mr Hendrick Potgeiter came in
as far as the Cashan mountains
whence a Caffre chief named
15Mosilikatze had been expelled
by the well known ^ Caffre Dingaan, and
a glad welcome was given them
by the Bechuana tribes who had just
escaped the hard sway of that cruel
20chieftain - They came with the
prestige of white men and deliverers,
but the Bechuanas soon found
that as they express it, "that Mosilikatze
was cruel to his enemies but {and} kind to those
25he conquered, but the Boers destroy
their enemies and make slaves
of their friends" - The tribes who still
retain the semblance of independence
are forced to performed all the labour
3021 of the fields - as [manuring the land,
weeding, reaping, building - making
dams, and canals and at the
same time to support themselves -
I have myself been an eyewitness
35of Boers coming to a village according [0062]
66 59
to their usual custom and demanding
twenty or thirty women to weed gardens,
and have seen the {ose} women proceed
5to the scene of unrequited toil carrying
their ^ own food on their heads - and
their children on their backs and

and so far from any wish to conceal
10the meaness of employing unpaid
labour ^ Every one from Mr Potgeiter and

lauded theirhis own humanity &
justice in making such a fine
15 [equitable ^] regulation - ^ "We make "the people work for
us in consideration of allowing
them to live in our country" I
can appeal to the Commandant
Kru {ie}ger if the foregoing is not a
20fair and impartial statement
of his own and ^ his people's views -
I am sensible of no mental bias
towards or against these boers
and during the manyseveral journies
25I made to the poor enslaved tribes
never avoided the whites but
tried to cure & to administer remedies to the
sick without money and without
price - It is due to them to state that
30I was invariably treated by them
with respect, but it is most
unfortunate that they should have
been left by their own church for

35and become so {as} much degraded

67 60
/ This new species of slavery they have
adopted serves to supply the lack of
field labour only - The demand
5for domestic servants must be met
by forays on tribes which have
good supplies of cattle - The Portuguese
can quote instances in which
blacks become so degraded by love
10of strong drinks as actually to
sell themselves - but never in
anyone case within the memory
of man has a Bechuana chief
sold his people or a Bechuana
15man his child - Hence the necessity
for a foray to seize children and
those individuals Boers who would
not engage in it for the sake of
slaves seldom can resist the
20 [twofold] plea of a well told story of an
intended ^ uprising of the devoted
tribe, and handsome pay in
the division of the captured cattle -
[besides - ] It is difficult for a person in
25a civilised country to concieve
[that] if any body of men possessing
the common attributes of
humanity, (and these boers are
by no means destitute of the
30finer feelings of our nature), with
one accord ^ would setting out & after
loading their own wives and
children with kisses, & ^ and proceeding

35men of a different colour, it is
                                            true, [0064]
68 61
but possessed of domestic feelings
and longings equal to their own - I It
was long before I could give
5credit to the tales of bloodshed
told me {by} native witnesses, and had
I found no other testimony I should
probably ^ have continued ↪ to this day
⎰sceptical⎱ as to their authenticity -
10but when I found these Boers
themselves; some bewailing and
denouncing; others glorying in
the ^ bloody scenes in which they had
been themselves the actors I was
15compelled to admit the validity
of the testimony and try to
account for the ^ cruel anomaly -
They are all traditionally religious
having tracing their descent to
20some of the best men the world
ever saw - Hence they claim to
themselves the title of "Christians" &
all the coloured race are "black
property" "or creatures" - They being
25the chosen people of God
the heathen are given to them
for an inheritance, and they
as & were the Jews, are the rod
of Divine vengeance on the
30Heathen - Living in the midst of
a much larger population than
themselves and at fountains
removed at distances of many
miles from each other they
35feel somewhat in the same position
[as do] that the Americans in the Southern states [0065]
69 62
and when they recieve reports from
the disaffected or envious ^ natives against
any tribe it the case assumes all the
5proportions of regular insurrection
Severe measures then appear
to the most mildly disposed among
them as imperatively called for -
And however bloody the massacre
10that follows no qualms of
conscience followensue It was iswas a dire
necessity for the sake of peace
Indeed the late Mr Hendrick Potgeiter
[most devoutly] believed himself to be the great
15peace maker of the country -


/ But how is it the natives
being so vastly superior in numbers
to the Boers do not rise and
annihilate them? The people
20among whom they live are Bechuanas
not Caffres, though no one would
ever learn that distinction from
a Boer, and history does not
contain one single instance
25in which even the Bechuanas
[even] who possess firearms have
attacked either the Boers or English
If there is such an instance
I am certain it is not generally
30known either beyond or in the
Cape Colony - They have defended
themselves when attacked as in
the cases of the ambush of Sechele
but never have engaged in
35offensive war with Europeans
nor have they ever been guilty of [0066]
70 63
We have a very different tale to tell
of the Caffres and the difference
has always been so patent to these
5border boers that ever since
"those magnificent savages" * [* Union Service
Gazette so styles them] obtained
possession of firearms not
one of them ever attempted to
settle in Caffreland or even
10face them as an enemy in the
field - The Boers have generally
manifested a marked antipathy
to anything but "long shot" warfare
and sidling away in their
15emigg {r}ations towards the more
effeminate Bechuanas, left
their quarrels with the caffres
to be settled by the English
and the wars to be paid for
20by English gold -


The Bakwains at Kolobeng
had the spectacle of various
tribes enslaved before their eyes
the Bakatla, the Batlokua, the
25Bahukeng, the Bamosetla
Two other tribes of Bakwain were
all groaning under the oppression
of unrequiting labour - This would
not have been felt such an evil,
30but the young men of those tribes
anxious to obtain cattle - the only
means of rising to respectability
on {among} their own people were in
the habit of sallying forth like our
35Irish and Highland shearers to [0067]
71 64
procure work in the Cape Colony -
There labouring three or four years
in building stone-dykes and dams
5for the Dutch Farmers, they were
well content [  ] if at the end of that
time they could return at the end of
that time with three {as} many cows,
After presenting one to their chief - they
10ranked as respectable men ^ in the tribe ever
afterwards - These volunteers were
highly esteemed among the Dutch under
the name Mantatees - They were paid
at the rate of one shilling a day and
15a large loaf of bread between
six of them - Numbers of them who
had seen me about 1200 miles
inland from the Cape recognized
me with ^ the loud laughter of joy
20when I was passing them at their
work in the Roggefelt & Bokkefelt
within a few days of Cape town
I w {sh}ould ap {be} borne out in my
statement ^ as literally true by elders in
25the Dutch Church to whom they
were working, that the system
was thoroughly satisfactory to both
parties, and I cannot believe
that there as a Boer ^ either in the Cashan
30 [or Magaliesberg ^] country who would deny that a
law was made to deprive these
labourers of their hardly earned
cattle for the very cogent reason
that "if they wanted to work let
35them work for us their masters"
I can never cease to be most [0068]
72 65
unfeignedly thankful that I was
not born in a land of slaves
No one can understand the effect of
5the unutterable meaness of the slave
system on the minds of those who,
but for the strange obliquity which
prevents them from feeling the
degradation of not being gentleman
10enough to pay for services
rendered, would be equal in
virtue to ourselves - Repudiation
becomes as natural to them as
"paying one's way" is to the rest of
15mankind -


/ Whenever a missionary lives
traders are sure to come - They are
mutually dependant and each
aids in the work of the other
20but all experience shews that the
two employments cannot be
combined in the same person -
Such a combination would not be
morally wrong for nothing would
25be more fair ^ and apostolical too than that the man
who devotes his life to the welfare of
a people should desire the temporal
advantages from upright tradingcommerce
which traders who aim exclusively
30at their own enrichment modestly
imagine ought to be left to them -
But though it would be right for
missionaries to trade the present
system renders it inexpedient
35to spend theany time in so doing - No one [0069]
73 66
with whom I ever came in contact
traded, and while the traders whom
theywe introduced into the country
5waxed rich the missionaries
have invariably remained poor
and died so -          The Jesuits were
wiser in their generation than we -
Theirs were large influential
10communities proceeding on
the system of turning the
abilities of every brother into
that channel in which he was
most likely to excel - One fond of
15Naturally history was allowed
to pursue his bent - - Another of {fond}
[of] literature found leizure to pursue

20searches of ivory and gold dust

25aiding effectually the bretheren
whom he had left at home -
We protestants with the comfortable

send {t} out agents missionaries on {with}
30a bare subsistence only, and are

35for not being worldy minded [0070]
74 67
which is about as wise as praising

5

/ English traders sold those articles
which the Boers most dread - viz
arms and ammunition - And
when the number of guns amounted
to five so much alarm was
10excited among our neighbours
that an expedition of several
hundred Boers was seriously
planned to come and deprive
the Bakwains of their guns -
15Knowing that the latter would
rather have fled to the Kalahari
Desert than deliver up their
weapons and become slaves
I proceeded to the Commandant
20Mr Gert Krieger and representing
the evils which any such
expedition would do prevailed
upon him to defer it - But
that point being granted the Boer
25wished to gain another which
was that I should beact as a spy over
the Bakwains - I explained the
impossibility of my complying
with his wish even though
30my principles as an Englishman
were not in the way, by referring
to an instance in which
Sechele had gone with his
whole force to punish an
35underchief without my knowledge [0071]
75 68
/ Kāke an underchief rebelled and
was led on in his rebellion by
a {his} fathers in law who had
5Qy explain been regicide in the case of
Sechele's father - Several of
those who remained faithful
were maltreated by Kake
while passing to the Desert in
10search of skins - We had just
come to live with the Bakwains
when this happened and Sechele
consulted me - I advised mild
measures but his messengers
15were taunted with the words - "He
only pretends to wish to follow
the advice of the teacher - he is {Sechele}
is a coward - let him come"
The next time the offence was
20repeated Sechele told me he
was going to hunt elephants
and as I knew the system
of espionage which prevails
among all the tribes I never
25made any enquiries on any
subject that would convey
the opinion that I distrusted
them - I gave credit to his
statement - He asked the loan
30of a black metal pot to cook
with as theirs of pottery are
brittle, I gave it and a handful
of salt and desired him to
send back two tidtbits - the proboscis
35and fore foot of the Elephant [0072]
76 69
and knew nothing more until
we saw the Bakwains carrying
home their wounded, and heard
5some of the women uttering the
loud wail of sorrow for the
dead and others pealing forth
the clear scream of victory -
It was clear that they had
1025 attacked and driven away [the
rebel - Mentioning this to the
Commandant in proof of
the impossibility of granting
his request, I had soon an
15example of how quickly a story
can grow among idle people
Knowing that I used a sextant
The five guns were within one
month magnified multiplied into into five
20 [a tale of] ^ five hundred, and the cooking pot
where? now in a museum [↪ at Cape town] was
magnified into a cannon -
"I had myself confessed to the
loan" - Where the five hundred
25guns came ^ from it was easy to
divine, for knowing that

thing of course - And as I must
