77 70
/ mountains" - ? Many of them
visited us afterwards some for
medical advice and others to
5trade in those very articles which
their own laws and policy
forbid - When I happened to
light stumble upon one of the
latter in the town with his
10muskets & powder displayed
he would begin an apology
on the ground that he was a
poor man &c which I always
cut short by frankly saying
15I had nothing to do with either
the Boers or their laws - Many
attempts were made during
these visits to elicit the truth
about the guns & cannon - And
20ignorant of the system of
espionage which prevails
expected eager enquiries were
made among those who could
jabber a little Dutch - It is
25noticeable that the system of
espionage is as well developed
among the savage tribes as
in Austria or Russia - It is
a proof of barbarism - Every
30man in a tribe feels himself
bound to tell the chief every thing
that comes to his knowledge
and when questioned either give
answers which exhibit the
35utmost stupidity or such as he
knows will be agreeable to [0074]
78 71
to his chief - I believe that in this
way have arisen tales of inability
to count ten or even smaller
5numbers - As Mr Burchel was
led to believe this of the Bechuanas
[about the very] at a time when Sechele's father
counted out one thousand head
of cattle as a beginning of the
10stock of his young son In the
present case Sechele knowing
every question put to his people
asked me how they ought to
answer - My reply was "tell
15the truth" Every one ^ then declared
that they had no cannon
[existed there] and our friends judging the
answer by what they themselves
would have in the circumstances
20have said, were confirmed in
the opinion that the Bakwains
actually possessed artillery - This
was so far beneficial as
fear prevented any foray
25in our direction for eight
years - During that time no
winter passed without one
or two tribes being plundered
of both cattle and children
30The plan pursued is the following
One or two friendly tribes
are forced to accompany them
a party of mounted boers and
these expeditions can be
35got up only in the winter when
horses can be used - [0075]
79 72
/ and when they reach the tribe to be
attacked the friendly natives are
ranged in front to form as they
5say a shield - The boers then
cooly fire over their heads till
the devoted people flee and
leave cattle wives and children
to the captors - This was done in
10nine cases during my residence
in the Interior and on no
occasion was a drop of Boer's
blood shed - Well, news of
these deeds spread quickly among
15the Bakwains and letters were
repeatedly sent to Sechele ordering
to come and surrender himself
as their vassal - and stop English
traders from coming into the
20country with firearms for sale
But the discovery of Lake
Ngami hereafter to be described
made the traders come in fivefold
[greater] numbers and Sechele replied
25"I was made an independent
chief ^ [^ & placed here] by God and not by you
I was never conquered by
Mosilikatze as those tribes whom
you rule over - And the English
30are my friends and I gave {get} me
everything I wish from them -
I cannot hinder them from
going where they like" Those who
are old enough to remember
35the threatened invasion of our
own island many understand [0076]
80 73
the effect which the constant danger
of a Boerish invasion had on
the minds of the Bakwains, but
5no others can appreciate concieve
how worrying were the messages
and threats from the endless
self constituted authorities of the
Magaliesberg burghers - and
10when that was combined
with the death produced by the
drought, we could not wonder
over though felt sorry for
their indisposition to recieve
15instruction -


The myth of the black pot assumed
serious proportions - I attempted
to benefit the tribes among the Boers
of Magaliesberg by placing native
20teachers at different points - "You
must teach the blacks" said Mr
Hendrick Potgeiter the thoog command
ant - "that they are not equal
to us" - Other Boers said I "might
25as well teach the Baboons on
the rocks as the Africans" but
declined ⎰to declined⎱ the test which
I proposed as to whether they
or my attendants could read
30best - Two clergymen came on
a baptising tour so supposing
these good men would assist
me in overcoming the repugnance
of their flock to the blacks being
35instructed I called on them -
but my visit ended in a [0077]
81 74
Qy ⎰"rusé"⎱ by the Boerish commandant
whereby I was led by professions
of the greatest friendship to
5retire to Kolonbeng and a letter
passed me by an other way
to the other missionaries in
the South demanding my
instant recal "for lending a
10cannon to their enemies" And the
Colonial Government was
gravely informed by my clerical
friends that the story was
true - and I came to be looked
15upon as a most suspicious
character


/ These notices of the Boers are
not intended to produce a sneer
at their ignorance but to excite
20the compassion of their friends
They are perpetually talking about
their laws but practically theirs
is only the law of the strongest
The Bakwains could never
25understand the changes which
took places in their commandants
"Why one can never know
who is the chief among the
Boers - They ^ have this king and are like the Bushmen
30and must be the Bushmen
of the English" The idea that
every tribe of men could be so
senseless as not to have a
hereditary chief was so absurd
35to those natives that in order [0078]
82 75
not to appear equally stupid I was
obliged to tell that we were so
anxious to preserve the royal
5blood we had made a little girl
our chief - This seemed to them
a most convincing proof of our
sound sense - We shall yet see
the confidence my account of
10our q {Q}ueen inspired farther on -


The Boers at last encouraged
by the accession of Mr Pretorius
determined at last to put a
stop to English traders going past
15Kolobeng by dispersing the
tribe of Bakwains and
expelling all missionaries - Sir
George Cathcart proclaimed
their independence - probably the
20best thing that could have been
done in the circumstances of
the case - The policy, however
of H. M. commissioner Owen
acting byunder the authority of that
25noble hearted man was very
questionable - These commissioners
anxious to conciliate the Dutch
Colonists often make monstrous
mistakes by taking forming
30an opinion of their character
through English Colonial channels
A late Governor for instance
had the idea that the Dutch farmers
[of the Cape] [^] are ferociously blood thirsty
35and when sorely pressed in Caffre war [0079]
83 76
actually called upon them to "exterminate
the Caffres in their own way - Not
a man responded to the Proclamation
5In point of humanity the English
border A treaty was entered
into by our commissioner andwith
these Boers and articles for
the free passage of Englishmen
10to the country beyond and
also foranother that no slavery should
be allowed in the independant
territory were duly inserted as
expressive of the views of H. M.
15Government at home - // What
about the missionaries enquired
the Boers - "You may do as
you please with them", is the
reported answer - It is difficult
20to believe that any Englishman
in that responsible position
could so far forget himself
and though the sentence uttered
perhaps in joke led immediately
25to the destruction of three mission
stations, it is probable that
designing men may have
circulated and caused the
the general belief as to its accuracy,
30it is impossible to avoid
a lingering suspicion seeing
this gentleman had been witness
of a Governor tearing a treaty
containing the Queens scope
35manual & in the presence
of thousands of Caffres scatter [0080]
84 77
/ the fragments to the winds - The
Boers 400 in number were
sent by the late Mr Pretorius to
5attack the Bakwains in 1852
and boasting that the English
had given up all the blacks
into their power and had agreed
to aid them in their subjugation
10by preventing all supplied &
ammunition from coming
into the Bechuana country
assaulted the Bakwains and
besides killing a considerable
15number carried off two hundred
of our school children into slavery
The natives under Sechele defended
themselves till the approach of
night obliged {enabled} them to flee to the mountains
20and having in that defence
killed a number of the Boersenemy &c -
the very first ever slain in the
country I recieved the credit of
having taught my tribe to kill
25Boers! My house which had
stood perfectly secure for years
in the protection of the natives
was plundered in revenge - English
gentlemen who had come in the
30footsteps of Mr Cumming to hunt
in the country beyond had also
deposited large quantities of
stores for the return journeys
and upwards of 80 head of cattle
35as relays were robbed of all, and [0081]
85 78
when they came to Kolobeng found
the skeletons of the guardians strewed
all over the place - The Books
5of a good library - my solace in
our solitude were not taken
away but handfuls of the leaves
torn out and both scattered
over the place - My stock of
10medicines were smashed but {and}
all over our furniture and clothing
carried off and sold at public
auction to pay the expenses of
the foray - I do not mention
15these things by way of making
a pitiful wail over my losses
to excite commiseration for
though I do feel sorry for the
loss of lexicons and dictionaries &c which had
20 the companions of my boyhood
yet after all the plundering only
set me entirely free for my
expedition in the North - and I have
never since had a moments
25concern for anything I left behind
The Boers would shut up the
Interior because on consulting the
ancient map in their old bibles they
see that Canaan & Cashan are
30not far apart - They being God's
own people can therefore claim
right up to Jerusalem - and keep
out all intruders - I resolved to
open up {the} country country and we
35shall see who has been most
successful in resolution - I or they

[0082]

to follow ⎰III IV?⎱                   ⎰86 [   ]⎱ 52 136 79


  The following memorandums are appended
      Having married Mary the eldest
daughter of Revd Robert Moffat
5in the hope that of Kuruman in ^ January 1845 a short sketch
of African Housekeeping may
[perhaps] prove interesting to the Reader - The entire absence
of shops leads us to make everything
we need from the raw materials
10You want bricks to build a house and
must forthwith proceed to the field
cut down a tree - and saw thatit into planks
to make the brick moulds - The materials
for doors and windows too are
15standing in the forest, and if you
want to be respected by the natives a
a decent house of decent dimensions
costing an immense amount of
manual labour must be built - The
20people cannot assist you much for
though most willing to labour for
wages the Bechuanas have a curious
inability to make or put things square
In our the case of three large houses, every
25brick and stick had to be put rightsquare by
my own right hands ⎡Having seen that
[got] the meal is ground and erected an
oven the wife is ready proceeds to make it into
bread - An extemporaneouse oven is
30often made by scooping out a large
hole in an anthill and using a slab of
stone for a door - Another ^ plan which might
be used by the Australians to produce
something better than their "dampers" is
35to make a good fire on a level piece
29 [of ground and when the ground is [0083]
53 80
thoroughly heated - place the dough
in a small short handled frying
pan or simply on the hot ashes,
5Invert any sort of metal pot
over it, draw the ashes around
and then make a small fire
on the top - Dough made with
a little from a former
10baking and allowed to stand
an hour or two in the sun
will by this process make
excellent bread


We made our own butter -
15a jar serving as a churn - - and our
own candles by means of moulds
and soap from the ashes of the
plant Salsola         - or from
wood ashes which in Africa
20contain so little of the alkaline
matter that the boiling of successive
leys has to be continued for a
month or six weeks before the
[fat is saponified] and there is not ^ much hardship in
25being pretty muchalmost entirely dependant
on ourselves - There is something
of the feeling which must
have animated ^ Alexander Selkirk
on seeing comfortsconveniences springing up
30before ^ him from one's {his} own ingenuity,
And married life is all the
sweeter when one sees so many
comforts emanati {e}ng directly
from the thrifty striving
35housewife's hands

[0084]

54 81
To some it may appear quite
a romantic mode of life,
It is one of active benevolence
5such as the good may enjoy
at home - Take a single
day as a sample of the
whole        We rose early because
however hot the day may
10 [have] been the evening, night and
morning ^ at Kolobeng were deliciously
refreshing - cool, is not the
idea where you have neither
an increase of cold nor heat
15to desire, and where you
can sit out till midnight
with no fear of coughs
andor Rheumatism - After
family worship and breakfast
20between six & seven we go went
[to keep] [^] to school for all who wish
[would] [^] attend, both men women &
children being invited - School being over
at 11 oclock we hav {d}e some
25manual labour as smiths
or carpenters or gardeners or
whatever may be needed for
ourselves or ^ for the people - If
for the latter they worked
30for us in the garden or other
employment - Skilled labour
[is {was}] then {thus} exchanged for the unskilled
Dinner [↪ and an hour's
rest] over at one {two} Mrs L to teach the wife
[attended] in ^ her infant school which
35the young who were left entirely [0085]
82 55
↪ ↪ [entirely] to their own caprice ⎰by their parents⎱
liked amazingly and generally
mustered a hundred strong -
5Or she varied that with a
sewing school having classes
of girls to learn that the art - this ↪
was equally well relished ⎰too⎱ -
Manual labour, occupied all the
10day before dinner in domestic
matters for everything operation must
be superintended - And both
husband & wife find manual
labour again necessary till
15the sun declines - The husband
then goes went into the town to
converse with any one
willing to do so - Sometimes
on general subjects at
20other times on those of religion
as the subjectconversation may [   ]take
[took ^] that turn - As soon as the
milking ^ of the cows iswas over and it has {d}
becomes dark we have {d} a
25public meeting religious service
during three nights of the week
and one of instruction on
secular subjects with aids {ed}
by pictures & specimens -
30These services are diversified
by attendance^ing upon and prescribing
[for] to the sick - giving food
and otherwise assisting the
poor and wretched - We try to
35gain their affections by [0086]
83 140 (56
by attending to the wants of the body -
The smallest acts of friendship
[an obliging] a civil word and civil look,
5are, as St Francis Xavier,
thought no despicable part
of the missionary armour
Here if anywhere love begets
love -


10

/ When at Kolobeng we {during}
[the droughts

never ^ wasted food though
Being alone we could not divide

15of getting a share in return
with any regularity - Sechele
had by right of chieftainship
the breast of every animal
slaughtered either at home
20or abroad and he most
obligingly sent us a liberal
share during the whole
period of our sojourn -
But these supplies were
25so necessarily so irregular ^ that we
were sometimes fain to
accept a dish of locusts -
These are quite a blessing
in the country - So much
30so ^ that the rain - doctors some-
times promise to bring them
by their incantations - They
[The Locusts] are strongly vegetable in taste
and that ^ [the flavour] varies with the
35plants on which they feed
There is a physiological reason [0087]
84 141 (57
why locusts and honey should
be eaten together - Those with
wings seldom do any harm
5Some are roasted and pounded
into meal which eaten with
a little salt is palatable - It
will keep thus for months;
Boiled they are disagreeable
10but when roasted, though
I would avoid both if
possible, I should much
prefer locusts to shrimps


In travelling we sometimes
15suffered considerably from
[scarcity] want of meat though not
from absolute want - This
was felt more especially by

20in order to shew kindness
[^ their sympathy] often gave ^ them a large kind
of caterpillar which they
seemed to relish , {-} They {se} insects
could not be unwholesome,
25for they natives devoured them
in large quantities themselves


Another article of which
our children partook with
eagerness was a very large
30frog - called "Matlametlo"*
footnote ⎰⎰* The Pyxicephalus adspersus

/ These enormous frogs which when
cooked look like chickens are supposed
5by the natives to fall down from
thunder clouds because after
a heavy thunder shower the pools
which are filled and retain
water a few days become instantly
10alive with these loud croaking
pugnacious game - This phenomenon
takes place in the driest parts of the
desert and in parts where to an ordinary
observer there is not a sign of life -
15Having been once benighted in a part
district of the Kalahari where there
was no prospect of getting water
for our cattle for a day or two
I was surprised to hear in the fine
20still evening the croaking of frogs
(the most dolorous musicians
can hear in those croaks [   ] tones
no [             ] sympathy with those
merry systems [      ] in Africa)
25Walking out untill I was certain that
the musicians were between me & our
fire I found that they could be merry
[on] with nothing else but a prospect of
rain - From the Bushmen I afterwards
30learned that the Matlametlo makes a
hole at the root of certain bushes [0089]
86 (59
and there enscounces himself
during the months of drought -
As he seldom emerges a
5large variety of spider takes
advantage of the hole and
makes hisits web accross the
orifice - He is thus furnished
with a window & screen gratis
10and no on but a Bushman
would think of searching
beneath the web for a frog -
They completely eluded my
search on the occasion
15referred to, and as they rush
forth into the hollows filled
by the thunder showers when
[the rain] that is actually falling and
the Bechuanas are cowering
20under cover their skin garments
the sudden chorus struck
[simultaneously] ^ up from all sides seems
to indicate a fall from
the clouds -


25

The presence of these Matlametlo
in the desert was rather a
disappointment for I had been
accustomed been to regard the
song as always emitted by them
30when Tantalus like they were
chin deep in water - Their
music was always the
most pleasant that met
the ear in the thirsty desert
35and I could fully appreciate [0090]
87 (60 144
the sympathy of Aesop, himself
an African, in his fable
of the "Boys & the Frogs."


5

/ It is remarkable that attempts
have not been made to any
extent to domesticate any
of the noble and useful creatures
10of Africa in England - The
Eland which is the most
magnificent of all antelopes
would grace the parks
of our nobility more than
15deer - This , from the excellence
of its flesh would be appropriate
to our own country and
as I have there is also a
splendid esculent frog nearly
20as large as a chicken it
will tend no doubt tend
to perpetuate the alliance if
we make a gift of that
to France


25

The Scavenger beetle
is one of the most useful
of all insects - as it effectually
answers the object indicated
by the name - Where they
30abound as at Kuruman
the villages are sweet
and clean for no sooner
is {are} animal excreta
dropt than attracted by
35the scent the scavengers [0091]
88 (61
are heard coming booming
up the wind        They roll
off the droppings of cattle
5at once in to pieces
often as large as cricke
billiard balls and
when they reach a place
proper by its softness
10for the deposit of their
young they dig the
soil out from beneath
till they have quite
covered the mass - Then
15deposit their eggs within
and as the larvae grow
they eat devour the inside
of the ball before coming
above ground to begin
20the world for themselves
They look with their gigantic
balls like Atlas with
the world on his back
only they go backwards
25and with their heads
down push with the hind legs
as if a boy should roll
a snow ball with his
legs while standing as we
30say on his head - As we
recommend the Eland to
John Bull, the gigantic
frog to France we can
confidently recommend this
35for the dirty Italian towns
and our own sanitory
                    commissioners

[0092]

V. 86 89
Coultart      =====


In trying to benefit the tribes living
under the Boers of the Cashan
5mountains I performed twice
a journey of about 230 {300} 300 miles
to the Eastward of Kolobong - Sechele
had become so obnoxious to the
Boers that though anxious to
10accompany me in my journey
he dared not trust himself
among them - [↪ This did not arise
from the crime of
cattle stealing for a
charge of that whichthat crime,
is so common among
the Caffres, was never
madecharged against his
tribe or indeed against
any Bechuana tribe
The crime isIt is in fact unknown
in the country except
induring actual warfare.
His independaence
& love of the English
were his only faults ] On my last
journey there of about 200 miles
he on parting with me at the
15 [River] Marikwe he gave me two
servants "to be" as he said
"his arms to serve me - " and
expressed regret that he could
not come himself - Suppose we
20went North, would you come?
He commencedthen ^ and gave
me the story of Sebituane saving
his life and expatiated
on the far famed generosity of
25that really great man - The {i}s
was the first time I had
thought of crossing the Desert
to Lake Ngami - The conduct
of the Boers in sending a letter
30 [↪ designed to produceprocure
30my removal out
30of the country] and their well known
settled policy - became as {which} I have
already relateddescribed, became
more fully developed on
this than on any former
35occasion - When I spoke [0093]
87 90
to Mr Hendrick Potgeiter of the danger of
hindering the gospel of Christ among

5excessivelygreatly excited [↪ and called on one
5of his followers
5to answer me, He
5threatened to
5attack any tribe
5that might recieve
5a native teacher
5but yet he] yet promised
to use his influence to prevent those
under him from throwing obstacles
in our way - I could however
percieve plainly that nothing more
10could be done in that direction
so I commenced getting all
the information I could about
the Desert with the intention
toof crossing it if possible: Sekomi
15the chief of the Bamangwato
[was acquainted with] had a pathroute which he kept
carefully to himself because
the Lake country abounded
in Ivory and he drew large
20quantities of itthence periodically
at but small cost to himself -
Sechele who valued highly
everything European and
was always quite wide
25 [fully alive] awake to his own interest
was naturally anxious to get

He was most anxious to

30perhaps from a wish to

having very exalted ideas
of the benefits he would
35derive from the liberality of
that renowned chieftain [0094]
88 91
In age ^ and family Sechele is the elder ^ and superior of
Sekomi, andfor when the original
tribe broke up [↪ into Bamangwato
Bangwaketse &
Bakuena] The Bakuena
5returned the hereditary chieftainship
So their chief Sechele possesses
certain advantages over Sekomi
the chief of the Bamangwato -
[ 33 Coult. If the two were travelling [↪ or hunting] together
10Sechele would take by
right the heads of the game
shot by Sekomi - There are
[several] ^ vestiges ^ besides of very ancient partitions
[and lordships] ^ of tribes - [↪ The elder brother of
Sechele's father became
blind and he gave
over the chieftainship
to Sechele's father - The
descendants of this
man pay no tribute
to Sechele and when
the ^ latter addresses the head
of the family he
calls him Kosi
or chief - though
Sechele in every other respect is
the ruler. ] The other tribes for
15 [instance ^] wontwill not begin to eat the early
pumpkins of a new crop
untill they hear that the
Bahurutse have "bitten it - " and
there is a public ceremony
20on the occasion - the son of
the chief being the first to taste
of the new harvest - Sechele
by my advice sent men to
Sekomi asking leave ^ for me to
25pass along his path for me
accompanying the request
with the present of an ox -
Sekomi's mother who
possesses great influence
30over him refused because
she had not been acknowledged
This produced a fresh message
and the most honourable
man ^ in the Bakwena tribe next to Sechele was
35sent with an ox ^ each for both
himself Sekomi & his mother
This too was met by refusal It [0095]
It was said "the Matibele the mortal enemies of
the Bechuanas are in the Ddirection of the
Lake and should they kill him we shall

5white men"

[0096]

89 92
The exact position of the Lake
had all along ^ for half a century at least been correctly
pointed out [↪ by the natives
who had visited it
when rains were
more copious in
the Desert - ] and many attempts
5had been made to reach it by
passing through the desert
in the direction indicated,
but it was found impossible
even for Griquas who having
10some Bushman blood in
them may be supposed more
capable of enduring thirst than
Europeans - It was clear then
that our only chance of success
15was by going round instead
of through the Desert - The best
# time for the attempt would have
been about the end of the rainy
season in March or April
20for then we should have been
likely to meet with pools of rain
water which always dry up
during ourthe rainless winter -
But having communicated
25my intention to an African
traveller Colonel Steele then Aid-de
camp to the Marquis of Tweedale
at Madras he made it known
to ourtwo other two gentlemen friends whom {se} we
30 [friendship we] had made byduring their African travel viz.
Captain Vardon and Mr
Oswel - All of these gentlemen
were so enamoured with African
hunting and African huntingdiscovery
35that I am sure the two former
envied the latter his fortune [0097]
90 5- 93
in being able to leave India to undertake
afresh the pleasures & pains of
desert life, I believe Mr O. came
5 [from his high position] at a very considerable pecuniary
sacrifice, and with no other
end in view but to extend
the boundaries of geographical
knowledge - When he Before I
10knew of his coming which he
₰ did by the overland passage
I had arranged that the payment
for guides furnished by Sechele
should be the loan of my
15waggon to bring out whatever
ivory he might obtain from
the chief at the Lake - And I
adhered to the bargain though
when at last Mr Oswel did
20come (bringing Mr Murray with him)
he undertook to defray the
entire expenses of ^ the guides, and
as he had already generously
presented a good new waggon
25to my little boy - though that
which I actually took to the Lake
[to perform Secheles work] ^ was ruined by the workjourney yet
it is plain that the whole of
the expenses of the discovery
30of Lake Ngami were borne
by the purse of this gentleman -


Sechele himself would have
come but fearing that the much
talked of assault of the Boers
35might take place during our

91 94
to me for taking him away, I
dissuaded him against it by
saying that he knew Mr Oswel
5"was {would} be as determined as himself
to get through the Desert - " Their objects
were ↪ totally different ⎰however⎱ -


Wilkes While waiting at Kolobong for
the company of Mr Oswel I may
10give some noticesaccount ^ of the great
Kalahari desert that the reader
may understand exactlyin some degree the
nature of the difficulties we had
to encounter -


15

The space betweenfrom the Orange
River in the South - Lat 29 - to
Lake Ngami in the North, and
from about 24˚ East Long
[to near] to the West coast has been
20called a Desert simply because
it contains no surrounding water
and very little ^ water in wells - It
is by no means destitute of
vegetation and inhabitants
25for it is covered with grass
and a great variety of
creeping plants - Besides
grass we havethere are large patches
of bushes and even trees
30Prodigious herds of It is
remarkably flat but intersectedc
in different parts by the
beds of ancient rivers, and
prodigious herds of certain
35antelopes which require little
or no water roam over [0099]
92 95
the tackless plains - The inhabitants
Bushmen and Bakalahari
prey on the game and on
5the countless numbers of
[a] small Rodentiaea and small
species of the feline race which
subsist on these - In general
the soil is light coloured
10silicious silica {soft} sand - nearly
pure silica - The beds of the ancient river havecontain much alluvial
soil in their bottoms and
as that is baked hard by
the burning sand, rain-
15water stands in pools in
some of these for somemanyseveral
months annually - in the year


The quantity of grass which
grows on this remarkable
20region is astonishing to
gentlemen even ^ to those who are
familiar with India - It usually
grows in tufts with bare
spaces between - or the latter
25are occupied by creeping
plants which having
their roots buried far
beneath the soil feel little
the effects of the scorching
30sun - The number of these
which have tuberous roots
is very great andas their structure if it were
[is] intended to supply nutriment
and moisture when during
35the long droughts they can [0100]
93 96
be obtained nowhere else - Here
we have ^ an examples of a plant
not generally tuber bearing
5becoming so in circumstances
where that appendage is
necessary to act as a
reservoir for preserving its
life - In Angola I shall refer to
10a species of grape bearing
vine which is so furnished
in and for the same purpose
that at present noticed is
one of the cucurbitaceae which
15bears a small scarlet coloured
eatable cucumber - Another
plant named "Leroshua" is a
blessing to the inhabitants
of the desert - We see a
20small plant with linear
leaves and stalk not thicker
than a crows quill & on digging down
a foot or 18 inches and you
[there are] we come to a tuber often as large
25as ^ the head of a young childs head - When
the rind is removed, we find
it to be a mass of cellular tissue
each filled with fluid much
like a pleasant sappy turnip
30and it is, from its depth
beneath the soil, generally
deliciously cool and
refreshing - Another kind
named mokuri is seen in
35other parts of the country
where long continued hot [0101]
94 97
[^] heat parches the soil - The plant
is a herbaceous creeper and
deposits a number of tubers
5some as large as a mans
head at spots in a circle
a yard or if it {m}ore horizontally
from the stem - The natives
percussstrike the ground on the
10circumference of the
circle with stones till by
hearing a different sound
they know the water bearing
tuber to be beneath - They
15then dig down a foot or
so and find it -


Robinson But Both the most surprising
plant of the desert is the
bitter water melon - In
20years when more than the
the usual quantity of rain
falls, prodigious tracts
of the country are literally
covered with them - these melons This
25was the case annually
when the fall of rain was
greater [↪ than it is now] and the Bakuena
sent trading parties every

30happened again as the cycle
of 10½ or eleven years occurred,
which for the last three

35wet season - Then animals [0102]

10                        ʅ

[0103]

The human inhabitants ^ of this tract of Country consist
of Bushmen and Bakalahari - The
former probably the aboriginales of
5the Southern position of the continent
the latter the remnants of the first
emigration of Bechuanas - The
Bushmen live in the desert from
choice, the Bakalahari from
10compulsion, & both possessing an
[intense] insatiable love of liberty - The
Bushmen are the only real nomades
in the country - they never
cultivate the soul nor rear any
15domestic animal save wretched
dogs - They are so intimately
acquainted with the habits of
the game that they follow them
in their migrations and prey
20upon them from place to
place & ^ thus provi {e}ng as naturalcompletely
a check upon ^ their inordinate increase
as the other carnivori are - Their
[The] chief subsistence ^ of the Bushmen is the meat of
25game but that is eked out by
what the women collect of

The Bakalahari are traditionally
[reported to be ^] the oldest of the Bechuana tribes
and they possessed enormous herds of the large horned cattle
mentioned by Bruce beforeuntil

20driven into the desert by a fresh

98 101 13
Living ever since on the same

supply a standing proof that

10for difference in races - The

15though often all they can ai {hope}

rear small herds of goats

They generally attach themselves
to influential men in the
25different Bechuana tribes living
a adjacent to their desert home

These are small carnivorae {i} of

or phukuye is very handsome

101 104

In the evening of our
second day at Serotli a
hyaena [[                        ] {↪ by appearing
suddenly among}
the grass] succeeded in raising
20a panic among our cattle
This ^ false attack is the plan which this
cowardly animal always
adopts - His courage resembles
closely that of a turkey cock - He
25will bite if an animal is
running away & if the animal
stands so does he - Seventeen
of our animalsdraught oxen ran away
and in their flight went right
30into the hands of Sekomi whom
from ^ his being unfriendly to our
success we had no particular
wish to see - Cattle stealing
such as in the circumstances
35might have occurred in Caffraria
is here unknown - So [0120]
112 115
Sekhomi sent back our oxen
and a message strongly dis-
-suading me against attempting
5the desert - Where are you going? "You will be killed
by the sun and thirst and then
all the white men will blame
me for not saving you - " This
was backed by a private message
10from his mother - "Why do
you pass me? I always made
the people collect to hear that
word you have got - What
guilt have I that you pass
15without looking at me" -
We replied by assuring the messengers
that white men would
attribute our deaths to our
own stupidity & "hard headedness"
20(tlogo, e thata) as we did not
intend to allow our companions
and guides to return till they
had put us into our graves"
We sent a handsome present
25to Sekomi and a promise ^ that if
he allowed the Bakalahari
to keep the wells open for

[on our return] After using upexhausting all their eloquence

Coultait All around Serotli the country
15is perfectly flat & composed

20one clump of trees and bushes

I sometime felt annoyed at
the low estimation in which
some of my hunting friends
5were held - for believing
that the chase is eminently con-
ducive to the formation of a
[brave &] noble character, and that the #
contest with wild beasts is well
10adapted for fostering that coolness
on emergencies and active presence
of mind which we all admire
I was naturally anxious to
havethat a high estimate of my
15countrymen ^ should be formed in the
native mind - "The {Have} these hunters
who come so far and work so
hard no meat at home?" Why
these men are rich and could
20slaughter oxen every day of
their lives" - And yet they
come here and endure so much
thirst for the sake of this dry
meat - none of which is equal
25to beef - ? Yes, it is for the sake
of play besides - (the idea of sport not
being in the language) This pro-
duces a laugh as much as

30"your friends are fools" - When
they can get a man to kill
large quantities of game for
them - whatever he may think
they pride themselves in having
35adroitly turned the folly of an [0125]
117 120
itinerant butcher to good account



Robinson The water ^ having at last flowed
5into the wells we had dug in

a good drink to all our

10sun even in winter as it now
was is always very powerful

[but slowly] heavily through the deep ^ heavy sand
[& we made] no more than six miles before
15sunset - We could only travel

as a single day in the hot sun
and heavy sand would have
knocked up the oxen - Next
20day we past {sed} Pepacheu - (white

and at night our trocheamer
25shewed ^ that we had made but

motobi was angry at the
slowness of our progress
and told us that the ^ next water being
30three days in front if we

never get there at all - Our {The}
utmost utmost endeavours
of the servants , by cracking their of
35whips - screaming & beating [0126]

got only nineteen miles out of the

got ^ proceeded 44 miles away from
5Serotli and the oxen were being {were} were
more exhausted by the soft soft
nature of the country than
if they had travelled double the
distance ^ at at {over} a hard countryroad
10containing water; we had still
as far as we could judge
still 30 miles more of the same
dry work before us them - The
grass was {b}ecomes so dry as
15to crumble to powder in the
hands at this season - So the oxen they
[poor beasts] stood wearily chewing without
taking a single fresh mouthful
and lowing painfully at the
20smell of water in our
vessels in the waggons -
We were all determined to
succeed, so endeavoured to
save the horses by sending
25them forward with the guide

was - They rush inIn they dash untill the
15water is deep enough to rise nearly

long refreshing mouthfuls
untill their formerly collapsed sides
20distend as if they would burst -

again ^ from their mouths - but as they have been
25days without food too
they very soon commence
to graze and of grass there

30Mathuluani; and thankful we
were to have obtained so welcome

When we left the Mokoko
Ramotobi seemed for the first
time to be at a loss as to which
10direction to traveltake - He had passed
only once away to the West of
the Mokoko the scenes of his
boyhood - But Mr Oswel while
riding in front of the waggons
15happened to spy a Bushwoman
running away in a bent
position in order to escape
observation - Thinking it to be
a lion he galloped ^ up to her - She
20thought herself captured and
began to deliver up her poor
[little] property consisting of a few
traps made of cords - But when
I explained that we only
25wanted water and would
pay her if she led us to it she
consented to conduct us to a
spring - It was then late in the
afternoon but she walked
30briskly before our horses
for eight miles and shewed
us the water of Nchokotsa -
After leading us to the water she
wished to go away home if
35indeed such she had ^ any, (she had
fled from a party of her [0131]
123 126
countrymen and was now living
far from all other & water
with her husband) but as it was
5now dark we wished her to
remain - ^ as she Believing {ed} herself still
a captive, we thought she might
slip away by night, so in
order that she mightshould not go away
10with the impression that we
were dishonest - we gave her
a piece of meat and a good
large bunch of beads, at the
sight of the latter she burst
15into a merry laugh and
remained without suspicion


Carp At Nchokotsa we came
upon the first of a great
number of salt pans
20covered with an efflorescence
of lime & nitrate of soda ? A thick belt of

30over the white incrustations

35made the poor Bushwoman
and Bakwains think him mad - [0132]
124 127
I was a little behind him and was

15

Looking to the West ^ & Nor West from

25perfection except over these saline
incrustations - Here not a

30collections of water - The waves
danced along above and the

Wilkes Next day when we were
5quite disposed to be friendly
with every one, two of the
Bamangwato, who had
been sent on before us
by Sekomi to drive away
10all the Bushmen and

came and sat down by our
fire - We had seen their footsteps
fresh in the way, and they had
15watched our slow movements
forward, and wondered to
see how we, without any
bushmen, found our way
to the waters - This was the
20first time they had seen
Ramotobi - "You have reached
the river now", said they;
and we, quite disposed to laugh
as having won the game, felt
25no ill will to any one - They
felt no enmity to us, but
after friendly conversation with
us proceeded to fulfill to the
last the instructions of their
30chief = (.) Ascending the Zouga
in our front, they circulated
the report that our objects
were to plunder all the tribes
living on the river and Lake;
35But when ^ they had got half way up the [0135]
127 130
river, the principal man
sickened of fever, turned
back some distance, and died
5His death had some effect
for the villagers connected
it with the injury he was
attempting to do to us - They
all saw through Sekomi's
10reasons for wishing us to
fail in our attempt; and
though they cam armed to
us at first, kind & fair
treatment soon produced
15perfect confidence


When we had gone up the
bank of this beautiful river
about 96 miles from the point
where we first struck it, and
20understood that we were still
a considerable distance from
the Ngami, all the waggons
and oxen ⎰were lefthere⎱ except Mr
Oswel's, which was the smallest
25and one team, - ↪ in the hope that
they rest would be recruited for
the home journey, while we
made a push for the Lake -
The Bechuana chief of the lake
30region, who had sent men to
Sechele, now sent order to
all the people on the river to
assist us, and we were
recieved by the Bakoba, whose
35language ^ clearly shews they bear [0136]
128 131
an affinity to the tribes in the
North - (.) They call themselves
Bayeiye, i-e- men; but the
5Bechuanas use the term Bakoba,
which contains somewhat of
the idea of slaves. - They have
never been known to fight,
and indeed have a tradition
10that their forefathers in their
first essays at war made
their bows of the Palma Christi;
and when these broke, they
gave up fighting altogether. - They
15have invariably submitted
to the rule of every horde which
has overrun the countries
adjacent to the rivers on
which they specially love to
20dwell. - They are thus the Quakers
of the body politic in Africa -


Robinson A ( Long ^ time after ^ the period of our visit this the
chief of the Lake, thinking to
make soldiers of them, took
25the trouble to furnish them
with shields. - "Ah! we never
had these before; that is the
reason we have always
succumbed. - Now we will
30fight - " But a marauding
party came from the Makololo,
tr and our ^ "Friends" ↪ scouried ⎰at once⎱
away down the Zouga, - never
[daring to] once looking behind them
35till they reached the end of it
where we first saw it - )

[0137]

129 132
The canoes of these inland
sailors are truly primitive craft:
They are hollowed out of the
5trunks of single trees by means
of iron adzes; and if the tree
has a bend, so has the canoe(.)
I liked the frank and manly
bearing of these inland sailors,
10and instead of sitting in the
waggon preferred a seat
in ^ one of the canoes. - I found
they regarded their rude vessels
as the Arab does his camel(.)
15They have always a fires in
[them] each, and prefer sleeping in
them while on a journey to
spending the night on shore(.)
"On land you have lions," - say
20they; - "serpents, hyaenas, and
your enemies; but in your
canoe behind a bank of
reed nothing can harm you - "
Their submissive disposition
25leads to their villages being frequently
visited by hungry strangers (-) We
had a pot on the fire o {i}n the
canoe by the way, and when
we drew near the villages
30devoured the contents (-) When
fully satisfied ourselves, I found
we could all look upon
any intruders with perfect
complacency, and shew the
35pot in proof of having devoured
the last morsel -

[0138]

130 45 133
While ascending in this way
this beautifully wood ^ ed river,
we came to a large riverstream
5flowing into it - : This was / the
[River ^] Tamunak'le(.) I enquired
whence it came(.) "O, from a
country full of river - so
many no one can tell their
10number, and full of large
trees -" This was the first con-
firmation of statements I had

25came to the Lake, ^ itthe idea occupied

seemed of but little importance(:)

30caused by the magnificent

35a charge by {w}hich I wished

131 134
"had ever been accomplished
in the world without it." *


/ Daintree & Co. Twelve days after our
5departure from the waggons
at Ngabisane we came to
the North East end of Lake
Ngami and on the 1st August
1849 we went down together
10to the broad part and for
the first time this fine looking
sheet of water was beheld
by Europeans Eyes - The direction
of the Lake seemed to be N. N - E -
15and S - S - W - ^ by compass The Southern portion
is said to bend a little round
to the West, & to recieve the Teoughe
from the North at its N - W
extremity - We could detect no
20horizon where we stood looking
S - S - W - We could form no
idea of its extent except from
nativethe reports ^ of the natives and as they
professed to go round it in
25three days, allowing 25 miles
a day that would bemake it 75 or
less than 70 geographical
miles in circumference - Other
guesses have been made since
30 [as to its circumference,] and they rangeing between 70
and 100 miles in circumference

 
* Letters published by the Royal Geographical
35society - Read - 11th Feb. & 8 April 1850 [0140]
132 135
It is shallow for I subsequently
saw a native punting his
canoe over 7 or 8 miles of
5the N - E - end , and ^ it can never
be of much value as a
commercial highway - In
the months preceding the
annual supply of water
10from the North it ^ the Lake is so lowshallow
that it is with difficulty ^ that cattle
can approach the water
through the boggy reedy banks
These are low on all sides
15but on the West there is a
space devoid of trees shewing
that the waters have retired
from thence at no very
ancient date - This is just
20another of the proofs of
desiccation so {m}et ^ with so abundantly
[throughout] in the whole country - A
number of dead trees lie on

25embedded in the mud right
in the water - We were informed

inundation begins, not

Antelopes as the Springbuck
[and Tsessebe] (acronotus Lunata)

133 136 48
The water of the Lake is perfectly

It is the Southern & lowest
20part of the great river system
beyond - ︹ In itwhich large tracts

25A little of that water which in

discharges itself into the Zouga -

10of the Tamunakle and ˄ and an arm of

where the one ends and the other begins
This last is narrow and shallow
while the Zouga is broad and deep
15This {e} narrow arm of the Lake which
[on the map] looks like a continuation of the Zouga
has never been observed to flow
either way - It is as stagnant as
the Lake itself - The Teouge flows
20into and Tamunakle being essentially
the same river and recieving
their supplies from the same source
(the Embarrah) Varra can never outrun
each other - If either could, or if
25the Teoughe could fill the Lake, a
thing which has never happened in
modern times Then this little arm
would prove a convenient
escapement to prevent inundation
30If the Lake ever becomes lower
than the bed of the Zouga a little

35the phenomenon of a river flowing

135 138 50
been observed to take place here and
it is doubtful if ˄ it ever can occur - ˄ in this locality - The

5leaves the Tamunakle but becomes

10and 12 long - The water which
higher up began to flow in April
does not make much progress in

/ My chief object in coming
to the Lake was to visit Sebituane
the great chief of the Makololo who
was reported to live some 200
miles beyond - We had now
20come to a half tribe of the Bamang
-wato called Batauana. underTheir chief was
a young man named Lechulatébe
Sebituane had conquered his father
Moremi, and Lechulatébe recieved
25part of his education ˄ while a captive among
the Bakoba Bayeiye - His uncle
a sensible man ransomed him
and having collected a number
of families together abdicated the
30chieftainship in favour of his
nephew - As Lechulatebe had
first come into power he
imagined that the proper way
of shewing his abilities was
35to act directly contrary to every
thing that his uncle advised [0145]
137 140
When we came the uncle recommended
handsome treatment, therefore the
hopeful youth presented us with
5a goat only - It ought to have been
an ox - So I proposed to ˄ to my companions to loose
the animal and let him go as
a hint to his master - My com-
-panions They however did not
10wish to insult him - I being more
of a native thought "he began it"
We wished to purchase some
goats or oxen - Lechulatebe
offered us elephants' tusks -
15"No we cannot eat these - we
want something to fill our stomachs"
"Neither can I, But I see {hear} you
[white men] are all very fond of these bones
so I offer them, I want to
20put the goats into my own stomach"
A trader who accompanied us
was then purchasing ivory at
the rate of ten good large tusks
for a musket worth thirteen shillings
25They were called "bones" and
I myself saw eight casesinstances in
which the tusks had been
left to rot with the other bones
[where] of the elephant where he fell -
30The Batauana never had a
chance of a market before - but
in less than two years afterward
after our discovery not a man
of them could be found who
35was not keenly alive to the
[great value] preciousness of the article

[0146]

138 141


On the day after our arrival at
the Lake I applied to Lechulatebe
for guides to Sebituane, As he
5was much afraid of that
chief he objected on the score
of fearing lest other white men
w {s}hould go the thither also and give
Sebituane guns, butwhereas if the
10traders came to him alone the
possession of firearms would
give him such a superiority
that Sebituane would be
afraid of him - It was in
15vain to explain that I would
inculcate peace between them. - that
Sebituane had been a father to
him and Sechele, and was as
anxious to see me as he ˄ (Lechulatebe) had been
20He offered to give me as much
ivory as I needed without
going to that chief - But when
we {I} refused to take any he
unwillingly consented to give
25guides - Next day however
when Oswel and I were prepared
to start with the horses only, we
recieved a senseless refusal
[& Like like] He, Sekomi - like, ˄ he sent men to
30the Bayeiye with orders to refuse
us passage accross the river -
Trying to form a raft at a
narrow part I worked many
hours in the water but the dry
35wood was so worm eaten [0147]
139 142
it would not bear the weight of a
single person - I was not then
aware of the numbers of alligators
5which exist in the Zouga and
never remember my labour in
the water without feeling thankful
that I escaped their jaws, The
season was now far advanced
10and as Mr O, with his wonted generous
feelings volunteered on the spot to
go down to the Cape and bring up
a boat we resolved to make our
way South again -


15

Coming down the Zouga
we hav {d}e now time to look at
its banks - These are very beautiful
resembling closely many parts
of the ever lovely River Clyde above
20Glasgow, The structure ˄ formation is soft
calcareous tufa such as forms
the bottom of all this basin -
Perpendicular on the side to
which the water swings and
25sloping and grassy on the other -
on The slopes ˄ are selected for the pitfalls designed
by the Bayeiye to entrap the
animals as they come to drink
They are about seven ˄ or eight feet deep
30Three or four feet wide at the
mouth and gradually decreasing
till they are ˄ only about a foot wide
at the bottom - The mouth is square
[an oblong square] (the only square thing made by
35the Bechuanas for everything
else is round) and the long [0148]
140 143 55
diameter at the surface is about
equal to the depth - The decreasing
width towards the bottom is
5intended to make the animal wedge
himself more firmly in by his
weight and struggles - They are
usually in pairs with a wall
of a foot in diameterthick between
10them ends of each - {figure} So
that if the beast should save
himself by striding the hind legs
[he would] he springs forward to save himself
and leaps into the second with
15a force which insures the precipitationfall
of thehis whole body into the trap - They
are covered with great care
all the ˄ excavated ground is removed to a
distance - so as not to excite suspicion
20A coveringceiling is made of reeds &
grass above these the sand is
thrown and watered so as to
appear exactly like the rest of
the spot - Some of our party
25plumped into them more than
once even when in search of
them in order to open them
to prevent the loss of our cattle
If an ox sees a hole he carefully
30avoids it And old Elephants
have been known to precede
the herd and whisk off the coverings
of the pitfalls on each side of him
all the way down to the water
35We have seen instances in which
[the old] ofamong these sagacious animals had [0149]
141 144
actually lifted the young out of the
trap


The animals which abound in
5the country ajdacent -


/ The trees which adorn the banks
are magnificent - Two enormous
Baobabs (Adansonia digitata) or Mo˄uanas groEw at the spot where we
took the observations for the
10Latitude (20° 20' - S) - The Longitude of the Lake
[has] nevernot been ascertained as our watches
were useless - It may be between 22° & 23°E.)
The largest of these ˄ trees was 76 feet in
girth - The Palmyra appears here
15and there among the trees not met
within the South - The Mokuchong
or Mashoma bears an edible
fruit of indifferent quality but
the tree itself would be a fine
20specimen of arboreal beauty in
Qu: this word any part of the world - The bole
is often converted into canoes,
The Motsouri, which bears
a scarlet plum containing a
25pleasant acid juice, resembling
an orange tree byin its dark ˄ ever green
foliage and a cypress by in
its form - Wild We were there
in the winter and saw nothing of
30the flora - The plants and bushes
were dry - But wild Indigo abounded
as indeed it does over large tracts
of country of Africa - It is called
Mohetolo or the "changer" by the
35boys who dye their ornaments of [0150]
142 145
straw with the juice - There are two kinds
of cotton in the country and the
Mashona who convert it into cloth
5dye it blue with this plant -


We found the elephants in prodigious
numbers on the southern bank - They
came to drink by night and - after having
slaked their thirst - in doing which
10they throw large quantities ˄ of water over
themselves and scream with
delight - they shewevince their horror of
pitfalls by setting off in a straight
line to the desert and never diverge
15till they are eight or ten miles off
They are smaller here than in they
countries farther south - At the Limpopo
for instance they are upwards
of twelve feet high here only eleven
20Farther North we shall find
them nine ˄ feet only - The Khoodoo or
tolo seemed smaller too than
those we had been accustomed to
We saw specimens of the Kuabaōba
25or straight horned Rhinoceros
                      a variety of the white

and found that from the horn
being projected downwards it
30did not obstruct the line of
vision and make itso that this species was enabled
to be much more wary that its
neighbour -                    --


We discovered an entirely
35new species of antelope called
Lechē or Lechui - It is a beautiful [0151]
143 146
water antelope of a ˄ light brownish yellow colour
Its horns, - exactly like those of the
aigoceros ellipsiprimnus - or water
5buck or Tumōga of the Bechuanas, -
rise from the head with a slight
bend back wards then curve forwards
at the points, The chest, belly and
orbits are nearly white, the front
10of the legs & ankles deep brown - From
the horns along the nape to the withers
the male has a small mane and
the tail of the same yellowish colour
with the rest of the skin and
15the tail has a tuft of black hair -
HeIt is never found far from a mile from water
- Islets in marshes & swamps are hisits
favourite haunts and we {it} is
quite unknown except in the
20central humid basin of Africa
Having a good deal of curiosity
[it] he haspresents a noble appearance as
he {it} stands gazing with head erect
at the approaching stranger - When
25 [it] he resolves to decamp h {it}e puts
lowers h {its}is head and lays his
horns down to a level with the
withers - ˄ he then begins with a
waddling trot which ends in
30a gallop and springing over
bushes like the Pallahs - He It
runs invariably ˄ runs to the water
and crosses it by a succession
of bounds - each of which
35appears to be from the bottom
We thought the flesh good at first
but soon got tired of it -

[0152]

144 147
Great shoals of excellent fish
come down annually with the
access of waters       The Mullet
5Mugil Africanus is the most abundant


[                ]

The Glanis Siluris a large
broad-headed fish without
scales and barbed called
10by the natives "Mosala" attains
an enormous size and
fatness - They are caught so
large ˄ that when a man carries
one over his shoulder the tail
15reaches the ground - It is a
vegetable feeder and in many
of its habits resembles the eel -
[# Another
closely resembling] ˄ This fish is named Clarias
capensis by Dr Smith - It is
20widely diffused throughout
the Interior and often leaves
the rivers for the sake of
feeding in pools - As these
dry up large numbers of them
25are entrapped by the natives [0153]
145 148 60
/ A water serpent yellow spotted
and dark brown is often
seen swimming along with
5his head above the water
HeIt is quite innocuous and
is relished ˄ as food by the Bayeye


They mention ten kinds of
fish in their river and in
10their songs of praise of the Zouga
say,       "the messenger sent
in haste is always forced to
spend the night in the way by the
abundance of food you place
15before him"


[                ]

The Bayeiye live much on
fish which is quite an abomination
to the Bechuanas in the South and
20they catch them in large numbers
by means of nets made of the
fine strong fibres of the Hibiscus
which grows abundantly in
all moist places - Their float
25ropes are made of the Ifé or [0154]
146 149
[as it is] ˄ now called, the Sanseviere angolensis - a
flag looking plant having a very
strong fibre that abounds from
5Kolobeng to Angola, and the floats
themselves are pieces of a water
plant                   containing valves
at each joint which retain the
air in cells about an inch long
10The ˄ mode of knotting of the nets is identical
with our own mode.


[                ]

They also spear the fish with
[Javelins] spears having a light handle
15which readily floats on the
surface - - AndThey shew great
dexterity in harpooning the
hippopotamus - & The barbed blade ˄
[of the spear] being attached to a rope
20of the young leaves of the
palmyra The animal cannot
rid himself of the canoe attached
to him in whale fashion except
by smashing it which he
25not unfrequently does by
his teeth or by a stroke of
his hind foot


[                ]

[                ]

Having returned to Kolobeng I and
5remained there till April of 1850, I and

had given orders to fill up the wells

15labour at Serotli, So we took

the Bamangw {u}ato town by {and} by
Letloche - That chief asked why

20journey and when I replied that

that ˄ I knew he did not wish me to go
to the Lake, and I did not wish to
quarrel with him, ˄ "Well" he said "Well
25you beat me and I am content"


Parting with Sechele at the ford
as he was eager to visit Lechulatebe
we went along the Northern woody
bank of the Zouga with
30great labour, in cuttinghaving to cut down [0156]
148 151
trees to allow the waggons to pass -
Our losses by oxen falling into
pitfalls were very greatheavy - The
5Bayeiye kindly opened them
when they knew of our approach
But when that was not the case
we could not blame no one but
ourselves on finding an established
10custom of the country inimical
to our interests - On approaching

we were informed that the fly
called Tsetse abounded on its
15banks - This was a barrier we
never expected to meet - and as
it couldmight have brought our
waggons to a complete stand in
[the wilderness] where no supplies for children
20could be obtained we were
reluctantly compelled to recross
the Zouga - From the Bayeiye

25to the Lake in search of ivory

so we travelled hastily down

5Lechulatebe to induce him

10He yielded - I had a very superior
London made gun the gift of

15impossibility of my replacing

whatever number of elephants

20would furnish Mrs L. with
meat all the time of my absence
This latter ˄ argument made me yield too
And though he had no ivory
at the time to pay me I felt
25the piece would be well spent
[on these terms] and delivered it ˄ to him - All being ready
for ˄ our departure I took Mrs L.
down six miles that she might
have a peep at the broad part
30of the Lake - She did not turn
up the white of her eyes nor act
the sentimental noany more than
I had myself done the year

35we had other work to do then

150 153 65
were seized with fever - On the

lay down too with ˄ the same com
5-plaint - As nothing is better

the hope of seeing Sebituane
that year so leaving my
10gun as part payment for
guides next year I leftwe started for
the pure air of the Desert - Some
mistake had happened in
the agreement with Mr Oswel
15for we met him on the Zouga
on our return, and he devoted
the rest of this season to Elephant
hunting at which the natives
universally declare he is the
20greatest adept that ever
came into the country - He
hunts without dogs - and it is
remarkable that this lordly animal
is so completely harassed by the
25presence of a few yelping curs
as to be quite incapable of
attending to man - He He It makes
awkward attempts to crush them
by falling on his his its knees - and
30sometimes places his his its forehead
[against] to a tree ten inches in diameter;
glancing at {by} on one side & then on, by the
other he he ^ the elephant pushes it down
before him as if he thought
35thereby to catch him enemies
The only danger the huntsman [0159]
151 154
apprehends is the dogs running
towards him - and thereby
leading the elephant to their
5master


[                ]

/ Foiled in this second attempt
to reach Sebituane we returned
again to Kolobeng, whither we
10were soon followed by a number
of messengers from that chief
himself - When he heard of our
attempts to visit him he despatched
three detachments of his men
15with thirteen brown cows to
Lechulatebe - thirteen white ˄ cows to
Sekomi and thirteen black
cows to Sechele with the a
request to each to assist
20the white men to reach him -
Their policy however was to keep
him out of view and act as his
agents in purchasing with his
ivory the goods he wanted -
25The policy is thoroughly African
and that continent being without
friths and arms of the sea as
Europe is, the tribes in the centre
have always been delivered from
30European intercourse by its
universal prevalence among
all the tribespeople around the coasts
Before setting out on our third
and successful journey to
35Sebituane - - it was necessary [0160]
152 155
to visit Kuruman and Sechele

however was more than usually

We passed quickly over a
hard country which is perfectly
flat - A little soil lying on
⎰ [over a tract of several] hundreds of miles⎱ of calcareous
30tufa ↪ supports a vegetation
of fine sweet short grass, and
Mopane and Baobab trees
In {On} several parts of this we
found large salt pans, one
35of which Ntwetwe is 15
miles broad & 100 long - [0161]
152 {3} 156
The latitude might have been
taken on its horizon as well

5

Although these curious
spots seem perfectly level, all
those in this direction have a
gentle slope to the North East
Thither the rain water which
10sometimes covers them gently
graduates - This it may be
recollected is the direction
of the Zouga - The salt dissolved
in the water had by this
15means all been translated to one
[pan] in that direction named Tlanye
[Chuantsa] , on it we see a cake of salt
and lime onean inch & a half inches
thick - All the others have
20an efflorescence of lime and
one of the nitrates only - and
some are covered so thickly
with shells identical with

25Lake and ˄ the Zouga they feel
quite crisp beneath the feet -
There are three varieties

30 [                ]

2 bivalve

univalve

[0162]

155 {4} 157
In every salt pan in the country
there is a spring of water on
one side - I can remember
5no exception to this rule - The
water of these springs is brackish
and contains the nitrate of soda
In one instance there are two ˄ springs and
one more saltish than the other
10If this supply came from beds
of rock salt it would ˄ not be
potable as it generally is - And in
[some] instances in whichwhere the salt
contained in the pan, in which
15these springs appear, has been
removed by human agency
no fresh deposit occurs
It is therefore probable that these
deposits of salt are the remains
20of the very slightly brackish Lakes
of antiquity large portions of
which must have been
dried out in the general desic-
-cation - This view seems
25supported by the fact that the
largest quantities of salt have
been found in the hollows
or lowest valleys which have
no outlet or outgoing gorge - ^
30⎰When theythese deposits ^ occur in a flat
[tufaceous] country like the present a
large space is devoid of vegetation

forward

35it in a state unfavourable to

And a fountain about 30 miles

5upwards of one 100° - and while

/ We found a ˄ great number of

15or the "Links" is quite a

springs - As they occasionally

20somewhat in this respect
the rivers we have already

percolation from the river
25system [↪ in the country] beyond - Among these
links we found many
families of Bushmen and
unlike those on the plains
of the Kalahari who are
30generally of short stature &
light yellow colour, these
were tall strapping fellows
and of dark complexion -
Heat alone does not produce
35blackness ˄ of skin but heat with [0164]
157 {6} 159
moisture seems to insure the
deepest hue - ᒥOne of these Bushmen
named Shobo consented to be
5our guide over the waste
between these springs and the
country of Sebituane - Shobo
gave us no hope of water forin

10 [Providentially,] however ˄ we came sooner than we

chain of pools - Beyond these
i {I}t is impossible to convey
15an idea of the dreary scene of

Not a bird or insect enlivened

20prospect I ever beheld, and
to make matters worse our
Guide Shobo wandered on the
seon˄dday - We coaxed him on
at night but he went to all
25points of the compass on the
trails of elephants which
had been here in the rainy
season, and then would sit
down in the path & in his
30broken Sichuana say - "All water
all country only" - {,} "Shobo sleeps",
he breaks down "country only"
and then cooly curl himself up
and go to sleep - The oxen
35were terribly fatigued & thirsty [0165]
158 {7} 160 72
and on the morning of the fourth
day Shobo after professing
ignorance of every thing
5vanished altogether - We went
on in the direction in which
we last saw him - and about
eleven oclock began to see
birds - Then the trail of a
10Rhinoceros - at this we unyoked

knowing the sign rushed
along to find the water in
Qu meaning ⎰the River Mababe⎱ [↪ which comes
from the
Tamunakle
and lay to

15The supply of water in the waggons

and only a small portion

20anxious night: and next

was the more thirsty the rogues
became - The idea of their
perishing before our eyes
25was terrible - It would ˄ almost have
been a relief ˄ to me to have been
reproached with being the
entire cause of the catastrophe
but not one syllable of that
30upbraiding was uttered bynature came from their mother
though the tearful eye told the

VIII 158 161 73


The cattle in rushing along to the water
in the Mababe probably crossed a small
patch of of ˄ trees containing Tsetse an insect which was
5 [shortly] to become a perfect pest to us -
Shobo had found his way to the
Bayeiye and now appeared when
we came up to the river with
[at the head] ofof a party of them and as he wished to
10shew his importance before his
friends he walked up boldly
and commanded our whole
cavalcade to stop - & to bring up {forth}
fire and tobacco while he
15coolly sat down and smoked
his pipe - It was such an inimitably
natural way of shewing off ˄ that we
all stopped to admire the acting
and though we {he} had left us
20at last, we all loved Shobo
a wonderful fine specimen
of that wonderful people the
Bushmen -


Next day we came to a village
25of Banajoa a tribe which
extends far to the Eastward
They were living on the borders
of a marsh in which the
X Mababe terminates - they had
30lost their crop of corn (Caffer sorghum)
and now subsided almost
entirely on the root called
X "Tsitla", a kind of aroidorioea which
contains a very large quantity of [0167]
159 162
sweet tasted starch - When dried
and pounded into meal and
allowed to ferment it is to
5an unpleasant food - The
women shave off all the hair
of their heads and seemed
darker than the Bechuanas
Their huts were built on poles
10and a fire is made beneath
in order that the smoke
may drive away the mosquitoes
which abound on the Mababe
and Tamunakle more
15than in any other part of
the country - The headman
of this village Majane seemed
seemed a little wanting in
ability but had ˄ had wit enough
20to promote a younger member
of the family to the office - This
person the most like the
ugly negro of the tobacconists'
shops I ever saw was called
25Moroa Majane or son of Majane
and proved an active
guide through the river
Sonta and to the banks of
the Chobe in the country
30of Sebituane - We had
come through another tsetse
district by night and our
passed over our cattle to
the Northern bank to preserve
35them from its ravages -

[0168]

160 163 75
/ A few remarks on the Tsetse,
[glossina morsitans] may here be appropriate - It is
not much larger than the
5common house fly and nearly
of the same brown colour as
the common honey bee - The after
part of the body has three or four
yellow bars accross it - The
10wings project beyond this
part considerably and it is
remarkably alert, al {v}oiding
most dexterously all attempts
to capture it with the hand
15at common temperatures,
In the cool of the mornings &
evenings it is less agile - Its
peculiar buz when once heard
can never be forgotten by
20the traveller whose means
of locomotion are domestic
animals, for it is well
known that the bite of this
poisonous insect is
25certain death to the ox - horse
and dog - In this journey
though we were not certainaware
of any great number ˄ having at
any time lightinged on our
30cattle we lost forty three head
[fine oxen ˄] by its bite - We watched them
carefully and believe that
not a score of flies were
ever upon them -


35

A most remarkable

[0169]
161 164
feature in the bite is its perfect
harmlessness in man and
wild animals and even
5calves so long as they continue
to suck the cows - We
lived two months in its habitat
which was in this case
as sharply defined as in
10many others for the south
bank of the Chobe was
infested by it and the
Northern bank [↪ where our
cattle were
placed] only 50 yds
distant contained not a
15single specimen - This was
the more remarkable as we
often saw natives carrying
over raw meat to the
opposite bank with many
20tsetse settled upon it -
The person does not seem
injected by a sting or by ova
placed beneath the skin
for when one is allowed
25to settle on the hand - it is
seen to insert the middle prong
[of three portions] into which the proboscis
divides itself; somewhat deeply
into the true skin: it then
30 [draws] withdraws it ˄ out a little way
and it assumes a crimson
colour as the mandibles
come into brisk operation -
[The previously] The before ˄ shrunken belly
35swells out and though
perfectly undisturbed the fly [0170]
162 165
quietly leavesdeparts when it is full -
A littleslight itchiness and irritation
follows but not more than
5in the bite of a mosquito -
In the ox this same bite produces
no more immediate effects
than in man - It does not
startle him as the gadfly does
10but a few days afterwards
the following symptoms
supervene - The eye ˄ & nose - begins
to run, the coat stares as
if the animal were cold -
15A swelling appears under
the jaw and sometimes at
the navel, and though the
animal continues to graze
emaciation commences
20accompanied with a
peculiar flaccidity of the
muscles, and it proceeds
unchecked untill perhaps
months afterwards, purging
25comes on and the animal
no longer able to graze
perishes in a state of extreme
exhaustion - Those which are
in good condition often
30perish with staggering ˄ & blindness as if
the brain were affecting {ed} soon
after the bite is infected -
Sudden changes of temperature
produced by falls of rain
35seem to hasten the progress
of the complaint, but in [0171]
163 166
but in general the emaciation
goes on uninterrupted for
months and do what we
5will they perish miserably -


When opened the cellular
tissue on the surface of the
body beneath the skin is
seen to be injected with
10air, as if a quantity of
soap bubles were scattered
over it or an dishonest
ackward butcher had been
trying to make it look fat.
15The fat is of a greenish yellow
colour and oily consistence
All the muscles are flabby &
the heart often so soft the
fingers may be made to
20meet through it- The lungs
and liver partake of the
disease - The stomach and
bowels are pale and empty
and the gall bladder is distended
25with bile -


These symptoms seem
to indicate what is probably
the case, a poison in the
blood - the germ of which
30enters when the proboscis
is inserted to draw blood -
Another insect will be
mentioned in which this
same operation produces
35in the human subject both
vomiting and purging [0172]
164 167
In this case the poison germ however
minute in quantity seems
capable of reproducing itself
5for the blood at death is
very small in quantity
and scarcely stains the hands
in dissection


The Mule, ass - and goat
10enjoy the same immunity
as man and the game -
Many large tribes in the
Zambesi lands can keep
no domestic animals
15except the goat in consequence
of the scourge existing in
their country - Our children
were frequently bitten yet
suffered no harm - and
20we saw around us
[numbers] herds of Zebras - buffaloes
[pigs,] pallahs & other antelopes,
feeding quietly in the very
habitat of the tsetse, yet
25as undisturbed by its bite
as oxen are when they
recieved the fatal poison
There is not so much
difference in the natures
30of the horse & Zebra -
The buffalo & ox - The
sheep and antelope - as
to afford any satisfactory
explanation of the phenomenon
35Is a man not as much
a domestic animal as a dog? [0173]
165 168 80
The curious feature in the case
that dogs ˄ perish though fed on milk (as the
calves which escape) which
5so long as they continue suckling
made us imagine that it
[the mischief] might be produced by some
plant in the locality but
[Major] Captain Frank Vardon
10of the Madras army had
settled that point by riding
a horse up to a small
hill infested by the insect
and though he only remained
15long enough to take a view
of the country and catch
some specimens from the
of tsetse on the animal
in ten days afterwards the
20horse was dead -


/ The well known disgust
which the tsetse shews to
animal excreta as exhibited
when a village settles is placed
25in its habitat has been
observed and acted on byturned to
[account by] some of the doctors - They
mixuse droppings of animals
human milk & some medicines
30together and smear the animals
[that are about] intended to pass through a
tsetse district - but this though
it proves a preventative at
the time is not permanent
35There is no cure ˄ yet known
for the disease - - A careless [0174]
166 169
herd allowing a large number
of cattle to wander intointo a
tsetse district loses all except
5the calves, and Sebituane
once lost nearly the entire
cattle of his tribe - very many
thousands, by unwittingly
coming into under its influence
10Inno-culation does not produceinsure

[                ]

The Makololo whom we

As he had been most

15and was unquestionably
the greatest man in all
that country, I may give
a short sketch of his life -
may prove interesting to the reader.


20

He seemed about 45 years
of age - of a tall & wiry form
and slightly bald - In manner
cool and collected and more
frank in his answers
25than any chief I ever met
He was the greatest warrior
ever heard of beyond the
colony for unlike Mosilikatz
and Dingaan &c - he always
30led his men into battle himself
When he saw the enemy
he felt the edge of his battle
axe and said "Aha! it is sharp
and whoever turns his back
35on the enemy will feel its edge" -

[0177]

169 172
So fleet of foot was he ˄ that all his
[people] knew there was no escape
for the coward [↪ He wasas any such would be cut
down without
mercy -] - In some
5instances of skulking he
allowed the individual to
return home - Then calling
him, he would say - "Ah, you
prefer dying at home to
10dying in the field ˄ do you?, you
shall have your desire" this
was the signal for his
[immediate] execution - This discipline
will explain what follows


15

He came from the sources

10like his so he moved down

His narrative resembles
15closely the "Commentaries

in India, He was always

20justify every step he took as

and feeling perfectly secure
25in their fastnesses often

to escape ˄ with him by night - The river
is so large that the clearestsharpest

5the between an island and a

But Sebituane with his

the island chief who ferried
10him accross to take his

and cattle were safely landed
15The whole Batoka country
was then densely peopled
and they had a curious foible
[weakness for] of ornamenting their villages
with the skulls of strangers
20When he appeared near the
great falls - an immense army
collected to make trophies
of the Makololo skulls - but
instead of that they gave him
25a good excuse of for conquering
them and capturing so many
cattle that his people were
quite incapable of taking
any note of the sheep and
30goats - He overran all the
high lands towards the Kafue
and settled in what is called
a pastoral country - short grass
little forest and gently undulating
35plains - The Makololo have [0182]
174 177
never lost their love for this
fine healthy spot -


But the Matibele a Kaffir
5 [or Zulau] tribe under Mosilikatze crossed
the Zambesi and attacking
him in this chosen spot captured
his cattle and women - Rallying
his men he followed and
10recaptured the whole - A fresh
attack was repulsed again
and Sebituane thought of
going farther down the
Zambesi to the country
15of the white men - He had an

[induced] led him to turn his face

25man by name Tlapane was

intercourse with the gods - He

30no one knew whither but probably

15the Barotse and taught his

20use their canoes without

all the Makalolo and their

25lay all around keeping

10

179 182
When he heard of our wish to

5Sechele - Sekomi and Lechulatebe

and the latter might have paid
dearly for his obstructiveness
He knew everything that
10happened in the country
for Sebituane had the art
of gaining the affections
of both of his own people and
of strangers - When a party
15of poor men came to sell

how ungainly they might
be he knew them all - And
never did a stranger depart
20from him without some
token of his generosity -
A party of the poor sitting

10were sounded far & wide

scarcely cut the skin - On

near said Sebituane &

25Robert to Maunku (one

to give him some milk"

30

We were not informed

so that it may be quite obliterated
We went and spoke to the

10the death to us - That Sebituane

He was decidedly the

/ During this foray the
5Makololo met some Arabs

In talking with my
companion over these
matters the idea was suggested
that if the slave market
15were supplied with articles
of European manufacture
in the way of by legitimate
trade commerce, the trade
in slaves would become
20impossible - It seemed
more feasible to give the goods
for which the people now part
with their servants in exchange
for ivory ^ [and other products

25the initiative trade - that {n}n to
put a stop to it ^ at any of the
subsequent steps - This
could only be effected by

30into the centre of the country
As there was no hope of
of the Boers allowing the

35I at once resolved to take
savesave my family from [0196]
7 191

5view to exploring the country
in search of a healthy
district that might prove
a centre of civilization
and open up the Interior
10by a path to either the
