This resolution led me down
to Cape Town in 18 {A}pril 1852
[being] the first time during eleven
15years that I had revisited
the scenes of civilization
      ======

[0197]
8 192

            The Cape Colony


In the minds of many English-
men I find the ideas of the
5Cape and Kaffre {ir} wars are
[as ^] inseparably connected as
the Siamese twins, and it is
somewhat difficult for those
who live on a railway
10island to realize the idea of
our little unprotected party
[quietly] travelling through the heart of
the colony to the capital [↪ in the twentieth
month of a
Kaffre {ir} war] with
as little sense of danger as
15if we had been in England
# These Kaffre {ir} wars are an
unmitigated nuisance - English
colonists are unquestionably
the best in the world - Neither
20French nor Spaniards nor
Portuguese can be compared
to the sturdy manly Englishman
[emigrant - ] He knows and acts on the
principle which other nations
25are so slow to learn that
wives are {and} families are more
essential to prosperous
settlements than kettledrums
and bayonets - The English
30wife must have a decent
house and things to match
and grumble as he willmay
he must follow her guidance
[so far, ^] and confess ^ that she is an essential [0198]
9 193 105
element in upholding and promoting
civilization - successful colonization


All my experience inclines
5me to the belief that in their dealings
[with the natives] of the English trader and Colonist
[have payssome] more regard is paid to the to justice
and honour than they assume
credit for - Nowhere can it
10be fairly said that the wide
world wide reputation of
the British merchant for
honest determination to fufill
his engagements, has been
15so entirely forgotten in an
English community as to
[have it publicly] considered a smart thing
to swindle [↪ either black
or white] the aboriginies -
To the poorest and most
20degraded the Englishman
says "Live and let live" and
that has been the general
feeling of the English Government
[too - ] The acts of different ministers
25have been capabe ^ it is true of bearing
another interpretation,
but it must be conceded
that no disposition has ever
[of late years] ^ at least been shewn by the English
30nation or Government
to exalt themselves by the
debasement of the less
favoured portions of humanity
t {T}here is even a general willingness
35to make considerable sacrifices
[for,] and to acknowledge the duty [0199]
10 194
of their civilization - But every
now and then we are forced
to hear of the happy homesteads
5of English settlers made desolate
by hordes of ruthless savages -
t {T}housands of sheep ^ & cattle are driven
off to be devoured in the mountain
fastnesses - The gardens and
10fields of the comfortable family
[families] are left desolate while those
whose industry would in
the course of a few years
have rendered them independent,
15if they have escaped with
life, are reduced to beggary -
English troops are then
sent to chastise the Kaffre {ir}s
[and avenge] for these fearful outrages,
20for it is quite abhorrent
to the English nature^ure to leave
[England's] her children unprotected
in the presence of these such
barbarians - The English
25soldier fights as bravely there
as anywhere else - The fatigues
of bush fighting are excessively
severe - and their privation
[which must be ^] endured in following a
30brave and crafty foe ^ are such
as can scarcely be imagined
by those who never saw
the fighting grounds - The
Officers are decimated
35by perpetual anxiety -
Kaffre {ir} bullets, and the [0200]
11 195
dead certainty that their labours
will be appreciated nowhere,
Millions of Pounds are
5cheerfully paid by ^ out of the British

of the Colonial Frontier,
but notwithstanding the
most lavish expenditure
10of money and men there
[never] is not the smallest probability
that ^ [^ a future] the nextanother outbreak will
be prevented -


As the period of our visit
15to the Cape happened to be coincident
with the termination of g {a} grand
experiment at a ^ towards a practical
solution of the great Caffre {Kaffir}
difficulty ↪ noticed ⎰above⎱ - [↪ though ^ and the
subject being

20# The interval between Caffre {Kaffir}
outbreaks had been prolonged
for a great many years
by what has been called
the Glenelg or "philanthropic
25policy" - This though not [perfectly well
25worked out] faultless was worthy of the
man whose name it bears,
and incomparably the least
expensive to the mother country
This policy was put an
30[                                    ] [0201]
12 196
an end to and a severer system
strongly advocated on the Frontier
called the "Durban policy" was
5tried - The former treated the
[C] Caffres {Kaffirs} as rational creatures
and presupposed that they had
some sort of natural title to
their lands and if we could
10keep a treaty so could they -
It also went on the basis
of the observation of common
honesty among ourselves as
well as among the Kaffirs {Caffres}
15and It was remarkably cheap
to the mother country -


The Durban policy presupposed
a willingness on the part of
the Dutch Colonists to turn out
20and exterminate the Kaffirs {Caffers}
if only allowed to do it in
their own way - This could
not be put into operation
because it is a libel to say
25that the Dutch in the Colony
are what the bloodthirsty people
this policy represented them
to be -


Another plan was tried
30by a gentleman conversant
with Indian Affairs - He wished
to adopt the Indian plan of
arming one part of the K {C}affirs
against another and disciplined
35a large body of the K {C}affir police - [0202]
13 197
then elected himself the paramount
chief of Kaffir {Caffre}land - He was
unconsciously dealing with the
5most devotedly loyal people
on earth - They never desert
[leave ^] the ranks of their chiefs as
French, Russians & even
Englishmen do desert to the enemy
10So when the watchword was
given by the great organ of
the war party "Send away
Sandillah" - The Kaffir {Caffre}
"Sippa-his" went off en masse
15to join their proper standard
in the Annatolans - Men whose
loyalty to their chiefs has
been but ^ only barely equalled but not
surpassed by that of the
20Highlanders to the Pretender
might one would think
have been turned to better
account than have every
feeling of their devotedness
25outraged by a foreigner
pretending to place himself
in the position of their
paramount chief Sandillah
To any one acquainted
30with the political constitution
of the South African tribes
no step could have been
devised better adapted for
rousing the wrath of the
35entire Kaffir {Caffre} people than [0203]
14 198
most impotent stab at their
nationality - Not even Sandillah
himself could have invented
5a more certain and efficient
means of rallying all the
chivalry of k {C}affirland around
him than that "a white man
who had been made a chief
10by a woman should depose
him who had been made a
chief by God" -


After a desperately
prolonged struggle in which
15upwards of two millions of
money were spent. the
Durban policy worked to
be {The} rather dear bought conclusion
was reached that the D'Urban
20policy is not the solution of the
Kaffir {Caffre} difficulty for it
was officially declared

25with the Circassians or

An experiment had
thus been fairly tried at the
30time of our arrival at the
Cape at {on} a large scale
and in exact accordance
with the ideasviews of a large

35measures were as severe [0204]
15 199
as the most bloody minded
could desire, yet we cannot
exterminate a single African
5tribe - The race is imperishable
as other things hereafter to be
noticed indicate this as well
Whether the Kaffirs are the
descendants of Ishmael may
10be gravely questioned - but
certain it is they do in
spite of all we can do "dwell
bravely in the presence of all
their brethren" - Their past
15seems to forbode that if we
follow the fighting policy
we can only hope for a
permanent peace when
we have depopulated all the
20country between Graham's
town and Timbuctu - And
as we have taken so long and
been at so much expense
with such small progress
25in that direction, such a
consummation implies
a postponement of the
Millennnium to please the
war party for some fifteen
30thousand years to come


/ If we knew the

10are the robbers - God made

When the son of God came
15down from Heaven you

20and break them - They make

30other countries - Is that

35have to answer before God" *

to R R Renton United Presbyterian church Scotland

[                ]

10

As the missionaries
petitioned in vain for a
commission to sift the
matter to the bottom, and
the C {K}affirs themselves are
15most anxious to discuss
the matter why should the
[it] matter not be fully investigate
In all our wars we have
had but one side of the
20question - We never hear

were compelled to hear the

operations in our late
25wars - Why not allow our
savage neighbours as we
call them the means of
explaining their views too [0227]
220
and wishes too - My Earnest hope
and prayer is that a Times
commissioner may anticipate
5the next Kaffir war by a
searching enquiry among

Colonists and I am certain
that if the causes of {of} this
10chronic warfare were laid
before the English public
as fairly as these gentlemen
can, the exposure would
go farther towards the prevention
15of another outbreak than
any measure that has yet
been proposed - They at least
will not be afraid of
meeting the Kaffirs in
20argument


[0228]
22d Jany 1857 221

                  Chapter First


The travels of which I now mean
to give a sketch extended from
5the Cape of Good Hope, the southern
extremity of the continent, to
St Paul di Loando, the capital
of Loando ^ [Angola] on the West Coast,
and thence accross the continent
10in an oblique direction to Quilimane
in Eastern Africa - They were
commenced in the beginning
of June 1851 {2} and terminated
in the end of May 1856, a period
15of four years, though not of
continuous travel, having been
spent in the ^ prosecution of the objects for which
the enterprise was undertaken -
And as no one but a German
20bookworm would think of
giving a detailed account of the
ever recurring minutiae of travel,
during that such as period, or lengthy
disquisitions on all that has been
25said and written from Hanno
down to our comfortable Easy chair
geographers who can fiercelykeenly
contend for the exact positions of
[places] about as well known as the garden
30of Eden, the reader may expect
from me that information and
those incidents alone which
attract my attention most stronly
and which I hope will convey

[0229]

X 182 116 222
                =====


Having sent my family home
to England I beganstarted ↪ mythe on my last
5journey from Cape Town on
⎰ [in] the beginning of June 1852⎱ which
[This journey] extended from the Southern
Extremity of the continent to
[St Paul di] Loando on {the} capital of Angola
10on the West coast and thence
accross the South central Africa
in an oblique direction to
Quilimane in Eastern Africa
I proceeded in the usual
15conveyance of the country,
the heavy lumbering Cape
waggon drawn by ten oxen
and was accompanied by
two [↪ Christian] Bechuanas from Kuruman
20who than whom I never saw
better servants anywhere - Two
Bakuena men and two
little ^ young girls who having come
as nurses with our children
25to the Cape were returning
to their home at Kolobeng
Waggon travelling in Africa
has been so often described
[that] I need say no more than
30 [it is] that waggon this life ^ it is is just
an prolonged system of pic-
-nicing - excellent for the
health and agreeable to those
who are not over fastidious [0230]
183 223
about trifles and ^ who delight in ^ being the
[in the] open air -


Our route on leavingto the North the
5Cape lay near the centre of the
Cone into which constitutes
the promontory of the Cape, If
we suppose this cone to be
divided into three zones or longitudinal bands, we find
10each presenting distinct
peculiarities of climate,
physical appearance and
population These are more
marked beyond thanan within
15the Colony - At some points
too, one district seems to be
continued intoin and merge into
the other, but the general
dissimilarity warrants the
20division as an aid to
memory - The Eastern zone
[is often furnished] ^ with mountainous {s}, well
wooded bywith ^ evergreen succulent trees [↪ on which
neither fire
nor droughts can
have the smallest effect]
[Streliezt Strelitzia] ( Zamias horrida - portulacaria afra
25Schotia speciosa, Euphorbias & Aloes arborescens)
and the ^ seaboard gorges with gigantic
timber - It is also ^ comparatively well
watered with streams and
flowing rivers - The annual
30supply of rain is considerable
and the inhabitants [↪ (Caffres or Zulas)] are
tall muscular and well
made. They are shrewd
energetic and brave and
35 [altogether] they merit the character given [0231]
184 224
them by military authorities of
being "magnificent savages"
Their splendid physical development
5and form of skull shew that but for the
black skin they would take rank ^ [among the foremost
Europeans]


The zone again which
embraces the centre of the
continent can scarcely be
10called hilly for it consists
of low hills and extensive
[&] slightly undulating plains
The latter predominate
and there are no lofty mountains
15There are few fountains
and fewer flowing streams
Rains areis far from abundant
and droughts may be expected
every few years - Without
20 [artificial] irrigation no European
grain can be raised, and
the inhabitants (Bechuanas)
though evidently of one stock
originally with those on the
25 [already mentioned] ^ East side of the continent
and closely resembling them
in being an agricultural as
well as a pastoral people
are a comparatively timid
30race, and inferior to the
[Kaffirs] Caffres in physical development



The Western zone is still
more level than the middle
35one, being rugged only near [0232]
185 225
The coast - It includes the
great plain called the Kalahari
desert which is remarkable
5for little water and very
considerable vegetation


The reason why so
little rain falls on this
extensive plain probably is
10this - The prevailing winds
of most of the ^ Interior country are
Easterly with a little Southing
The moisture taken up by
the atmosphere from the
15Indian Ocean is always
deposited on the Eastern
hilly slope and when the
moving mass of air the atmosphere
reaches its greatest elevation
20it is then on the verge of
the great valley or as
it is in the case of the Kalahari the
great heated inland plains
There meeting with the rarified
25air of that hot hot dry
surface the ascending heat
gives it greater capacity
for retaining all its
remaining humidity and
30few showers can be given
to the middle & Western lands
in consequence of the
increased hygrometric power


The large vegetation
35of the Kalahari so different

[0233]

186 226


This is the same phenomenon
on a gigantic scale which
takes place on Table mountain
5in what is called the spreading
of the table cloth - The South
East wind causes a mass
of air equal to the diameter
of the mountain lsuddenly
10to ascend at least a thousand
feet - The rarification produced
by altitude ^ & cold causes the immediate
formation of a cloud on the
summit, successive masses
15of air cause the continual
formation of clouds but
the summit top of the vapoury
mass or "Table cloth" is level
and seemingly motionless
20on the lee side however the
thick volumes of vapour
curl over and descend but
when they reach the point
below where greater density
25has greater capacity for
carrying water They entirely
disappear


Now if instead of a
hollow on the lee side of
30Table mountain we had
a heated plain the clouds
which curl over and disappear
as they do now might deposit
some moisture there
35but the heat would impart [0234]
187 227
impart the increased capacity
it now recieves at the lower
level and instead of an
5extended country with a
flora of the Disa grandiflora,
gladiolus, & rushes and lichens
we should have the hardy grassy
vegetation of the Kalahari


10

/ Why there should be
so much vegetation
on the Kalahari may be explained
by the geological formation
of the country - There is a {seems}
15 [to be] a rim or fringe of ancient
rocks all round the great
central valley which generally
dip into an ancient basin
wh the bottom of which is
20composed of the most
ancient Silurian rocks
This basin has been
burst through and filled
up in many parts by
25eruptive traps & Breccias
which often bear in
their substances ^ angular fragments
of the more ancient rocks
as shewn in the fossils
30they contain - Now though
large areas have been
so dislocated that but
little trace of the original
valley formation appears
35it is highly probable that [0235]
188 228
it still holds true of most of the
country and as the strata
on the slopes where most
5of the rain falls dip in towards
the centre they probably guide
water beneath plains but
ill supplied with moisture
from the clouds - The
10phenomenon of stagnant
fountains becoming by
a new outlet never
failing streams may be
confirmatory of the same
15view. And it is not

probability too that the
wonderful river system
in the North which if
20the native information
be correct influencescauses
the rise of the springs
called at N Matlomaganyana
(the links) extends its
25fertilising influence
beneath the plains of the
Kalahari

30there is & should be such a

The route we at this time

While in the Colony we passed
10through districts inhabited

French refugees from religious
persecution - Those living
near the Capital differ but
15little from the middle classes
in English rural counties
and excel in public spirit
and general intelligence
while those situated far from
20the centres of civilization
are less informed but are
a body of frugal, industrious,

25of public instruction was

30accomplished philosopher

Population among the Boers
increases rapidly - They marry
15soon - have children late
and are seldom sterile - I once
met a worthy matron whose
husband thought it right to
imitate ^ [the conduct of] Abraham while
20Sarah was barren; she evidently
agreed in the propriety of the
measure for she was pleased
to hear the children ^ by a mother of what
has been though an inferior
25race, ^ and they address her as their
mother - Orphans are never

When first taken possession of,
these parts are said to have been
covered with a coating of grass
5but that has disappeared with
the antelopes which fed upon

[and crassulas] occupy {ies} its place - It is
curious to observe how in
10nature, organismszations the most
dissimilar are mutually dependant
[^ upon Each other --- ^] for their perpetually {tion} ^ - Here the
grasses were dependant for

15feeding animals which scattered
the seeds - When by the death
of the antelopes no fresh sowing
was made the African droughts
proved too much for this form
20of vegetation But even this
contingency was foreseen
by the Omniscient One for as
we may now observe in the
Kalahari desert another family
25of plants (Mesembryanthemums) stood ready
to neutralize the aridity which
must otherwise have followed -
This [↪ family of] plants possesses a seed
vessels which remains firmly
30shut on itstheir contents while the
soil is hot and dry and
thus preserves the vegetative
power intact during the
highest heat of the Torrid
35sun, But when rain falls [0241]
194 234
the seed vessels openss and shedss
their its contents just when there is
the greatest probability of its their
5vegetating - In other plants
heat & drought cause the
seed vessels to burst
and shed their charge


/ One of this family h {i}s edible
10(Mesembryanthemum edule)
another possesses a tuberous
root which may be eaten raw
and all are furnished with
thick fleshy leaves having
15pores capable of imbibing and
retaining moisture from the
most unlikely atmosphere
and soil, so that if a leaf
is broken during a period
20of the greatest drought it shews
abundant circulating sap -
The plants of this species are
found much farther North
but the great abundance of the
25grasses prevents them from
making any shew - There
however they stand ready to
fill up any gap which may
occur in the present prevailing
30vegetation, and should the grasses
disappear animal life would
not necessarily be destroyed
because [↪ a reserve supply] an equivalent to
^ a fresh an act of creative power
35has been provided

[0242]

195 125 {235}


As this new vegetation is
better adapted for sheep and goats
in a dry country than grass the
5boers supplement the latter by
imitating the process by which
graminivorous antelopes have
so abundantly disseminated the
seed - A few waggon loads
10of Mesembryanthemum plants
in seed are brought to a
farm covered with a scanty
crop of course grass, and
placed on a spot to which
15the sheep have access in the
evenings - As they eat a little
every night the seeds are
dropped over the farm grazing
grounds in this simple way
20with a regularity with a regularity
which could not be matched
except by [at the cost of] an immense amount
of labour - The place ^ thus becomes
in the course of a few years
25as was intended a sheep farm
[                                                            ] [0243]
196 236
As already mentioned some
plants of this family are
furnished with an additional
5contrivance for withstanding #
70 droughts viz - oblong tubers
which buried deep enough
beneath the soil for complete
protection from the scorching
10sun, serve as reservoirs
of sap and nutriment during

recur perpetually in even the

15I have adverted to this peculiarity

25

/ The slow pace at which

continue like the Bushmen to

when all the rest are gone
The Elephant the most sagacious
10flees the sound of fire arms
first, The gnu and ostrich
the most wary and the most
stupid last The first emigrants
found the Hottentots in possession
15of prodigious herds of fine
cattle but no horses, asses
or camels - The original cattle
which may still be seen in
some parts of the frontier
20must have been brought
South from the North North
East for from this point
the natives universally ascribe
their original migration -
25They brought cattle sheep,
goats and dogs - Why not
the horse the delight of savage
hordes? Horses thrive well
in the Cape Colony when
30Qu: omit imported from ships - Naturalists
point out certain mountain
ranges as limiting the range
of certain classes of animals
but there is no Cordillera in
35Africa to answer that purpose [0246]
199 239
There being no visible barriers
between [↪ the North Eastern
Arabs and] the Bechuana and

5different hordes as they felt
their way Southwards to ˄ from indulge {ing}
their taste for the possession
of this noble animal I am

10 [barrier] more insurmountable than
mountain ranges, but which
is not opposed to the Southern
progress of cattle goats and
sheep - The Tsetse would
15prove a barrier only untill
they knew its well defined
habitat, but the disease
known as horse sickness
(peripneumonia) exists in
20such virulence over
nearly seven degrees of
latitude that no precaution
would be sufficient to save
theses animals - The horse
25is so amenable to this disease
that only by great care in
stabling can a horse be kept
anywhere between 20º S - & 27°
during the months time between
30December and April - The winter
beginning in the latter month
is the only period in which
Englishmen can hunt on
horseback and they are in
35danger of losing all their studs
some months before December [0247]
200 130240
/ To this disease the horse is
especially liable and it is almost
always fatal - One attack however
5seems to secure immunity
from a secondanother or rather
it proves thatwould seem as if nothing but
shooting him willwould kill the
horse which gets over it -
10Cattle too it is true are subject

but it never makes a

15a village as it would do

This barrier then seems to
explain the absence of the

20though it is not opposed to

cattle sheep and goats


/ When the flesh of animals
which die of this disease is
25eaten it causes a malignant
carbuncle which when it
appears over any important
organ proves rapidly fatal
It is more especially dangerous
30over the pit of the stomach
The virus ˄ in the flesh of the animal is neither destroyed

This disease attacks wild
animals too - During our residence

20of Tolos or Khoodoos were

The farms of the Boers con
15sist [consist] generally of a small patch
of cultivated land in the midst
of some miles of pasturage
They are thus less an agricultural
than ˄ a pastoral people - Each
20farm must have its fountain
and where no such supply of
water exists the Government
lands are unsaleable - An acre

25than a ˄ square mile in Africa - But
the country is prosperous and
capable of great improvement

30of dams and tanks and greater
fruitfulness -

203 243
/ As cattle and sheep farmers the
colonists are very successful
[Increasingly ˄] L {l}arge quantities of wool are
5produced annually and the

10there should be an extension

is and thinly inhabited, the
farmers feel it to be too smalllimited

15North - This movement proves
prejudicial to the country behind
for industrylabour which would
be directed to the improvement
of the Colony is withdrawn
20and expended in a mode of
life little adapted for the exercise
of industrial habits - That however
does not much concern the rest
of mankind - Nor does it seem
25 [much of] an evil for men who cultivate
the soil to claim a right to
appropriate lands which other

some com-
pensation for

sustenance

idea of a title seems to have
30been ˄ that "subduing" or cultivation {ng}

rather Chartist principle

for its recognition in England

15Basutas ˄ for instance actually raise

205 245 135
Before we came to the Orange
river we saw the last portion
of a migration of springbucks
5(Gazelle Euchore) or Tsépe) They
come from the great Kalahari
Desert and when seen after
first crossing the Colonial
boundary are said often
10to numberExceed forty thousand, ˄ in number
I cannot give an estimate
for they appear in vast
numbers expanses of country
and make a quivering motion
15as they feed & move and toss
their graceful antlers, They
feed chiefly on grass and
as they come ˄ from the North about
the time when the grass most
20abounds it cannot be want
of food that prompts the
movement - Nor is it want
ing water for this antelope
is one of the most abstemious
25Their nature prompts them to
seek, for their haunts, level
plains with short grass so
as to be able to watch the approach
of an enemy - The Bakalahari
30take advantage of this feeling
and burn off large patches
of grass - not only to attract the
game by the newly spring crop
when it comes but also
35to form bare spots for the springbuks

[0253]
XI 206 246

Robinson It is not the springbuck alone
that manifests this feeling - When
oxen are taken into a country
5of high grass they are much
more ready to be startled - Their
sense of danger is increased by
the increased power of concealment
possessed in the cover by theafforded to an enemy
10 [by such cover;] and they will often start off in
terror at the ill defined outlines
of each other - The springbuck
possessing this deep ^ seated feeling in
an eminentintense degree and being
15intens {emi}nently gregarious if {be}comes
uneasy as the grass of the
Kalahari becomes tall -
The vegetation being more
sparse in the more arid
20South naturally induces leads the
different herds to turn in
that direction - As they advance
and increase in numbers,
they pasturage becomes more
25scarce It - is ^ still more so still

On crossing the Orange river
we come into Independent
15territory inhabited by Griquas
and Bechuanas, The former
are of Dutch and Hottentot [↪ and bushman] extraction
of various degrees of remoteness
[Cross-breeds] Bastards of the first generations
20are {con}sider themselves superior
to those of the second, and
all possess in some degree the
characteristics of both parents.
They were governed for many
25years by an elected chief
named Waterboer who by
treaty recieved a salary about
£[   ] [small sum] per annum from the
Colonial Government for
30the support of schools in his
country and proved a most
efficient gaurd of our
North west boundary - Cattle
stealing has beenwas totally
35unknown during the whole
period of this able chiefs reign [0255]
208 248
and he actually drove back
singlehanded a formidable force
of marauding Mantatees that
5threatened to invade the Colony * Note [For an account
5 this see
5Moffats missionary
5enterprise "Scenes
5 Labours

[North] West frontier would have
10been as ^ given the Colonists as much troublesome as the

[original ^] Griquas were a had large

15farmers of cattle as has been

chieftainship he distinctly declared
that no marauding should
20be allowed - As the government
of all [↪ none of] these tribes is despotic
some of his principal men
went in spite of this declaration
and plundered some villages
25 [of Corannas ^] living to the South of the
Orange River - He immediately
seized six of the ringleaders
and though the step put his
own position in jeopardy
30he summoned his council
tried, condemned and publicly
executed the whole six - This
produced an insurrection
and the insurgents twice
35attacked his capital, (Griqua
town) with the intention of [0256]
[                ]

Having witnessed the deleterious
effects of the introduction of
ardent spirits among his
5people he with characteristic
energy decreed that any Boer
or Griqua bringing it
brandy into the country

10ardent spirits confiscated

15as he did - hence the greater

5his a long reign of thirty years not

Ten years after he was firmly
[established] seated in his power he entered

Many hundreds of both Griquas
and Bechuanas have become
Christians and partially civilized
5through the teaching of English
missionaries - My first

The Bechuanas Mission has been
[so far] so successful that when coming
from the Interior we always
5felt on reaching Kuruman

life - But I would not give

15 [respects the two] points they are exactly alike -

what he thought of them - He

no idea how wicked we are
20We know each other better than

some profess Christianity because

25gives so much more importance

large number profess because
30they are really true believers" - This
testimony may be considered as
about correct - The

The permanence of the station
called Kuruman depends entirely
on the fine ever flowing
fountain of that name - It comes
from beneath the Trap rock
20of which I shall have to speak
when describing the geology
of the entire country - and
as it usually flows out
[issues] at a temperature of 72° Fht., it
25probably comes from the
the silu old silurian schists which
formed the ^ bottom of the great primaeval
valley of the Continent - I could
not detect any diminution
30in the flow of this gushing
fountain during my residence
in the country but when Mr
Moffat first attempted a settlement [0269]
221 261 15
[here,] 35 years ago, he made a dam

Other parts fourteen miles

now living]
hippopotomi, and water sufficient
10to drown both men and cattle -

[chiefly] ascribed to the general desiccation

15both banks of the stream

latter l circumstance would

25Kuruman district presents

222 262
the flow of centuries has worn

Many of these failing fountains

[It is interesting to observe] the industry of themany Boers in this

why the ground covering the {i}s water

20carry quantities of fine dust and

hedges bushes & trees cause its

25hedges and the moisture rising

sand securely among the roots

is the result - While on this subject
30it may be added that there is

5highly probably that Artesian wells

5

During the period of my visit
at Kuruman Mr Moffat who has
been a missionary in Africa
during upwards of forty years
10and is well known by his
interesting work "scenes & labours
in South Africa" was busily
engaged in carrying through the
press with which his station
15is furnished the Bible in the
language of the Bechuanas,
This has been a work of immense
labour and as he was the first
to reduce their speech to a written
20form and has had his attention
directed to the study for at least
thirty years he may be supposed
to be the best adapted for the
task of any man living - Some
25idea [↪ the copiousness
25 the language]
[↪ of the extent of this task] may be formed [↪ of the copious-
ness] from the
fact that even he never spends
a week ^ at his work without finding ^ discovering new
words, {;} whether the phenomenon
30 [therefore,] of a man of {w}ho after a few
months or years study of a
native tongue cackles forth a
torrent of vocables is much
[may well] to be wondered at - [↪ it is meant
be instruction] In my own
35case though I have had m {as} much
intercourse with the purest idioms
as most Englishmen, [0276]
228 268
and have studied the language carefully
[yet] I can never utter an important
statement but ^ [without doing so ^] slowly and repeating it
5too - lest our unsure the foreign
accent which is distinctly per-
-ceptible in all Europeans should
render methe sense unintelligible - In this
I follow the example of their
10own spokesmen who on
important matters always speak
slowly, deliberately and with
reiteration - The capabilities
of this language may be inferred
15from the fact that the Pentateuch
is fully expressed in the ^ Mr Moffat's translation
in fewer words than in the Greek
Septuagint, and in a very considerably
smaller number than in our
20verbose English - ^ The languageIt is however
so simple in its construction that
it copiousness by no means
requires the explanation that
the people have fallen from a
25former state of civilization and
culture. Language seems to be
an attribute of the human mind
and thought - and the inflexions
proofs various as they are in
30the most barbarous (as the Bushmen)
are probably only proofs of the race
being human and endowed

of our other faculties - goes on

229 269
It is fortunate that the translation
of the bible has been effected before

5with foreign words - and while

of the ^ native assemblies are still living

10the language than the missionaries,

15referred to for explanation

20of the Basutas was not capable

ways -


In this language both rich
and poor speak correctly - There
30is no vulgar style - but children
have a patois of their own
using many words in their
play which men would scorn
to repeat - The Bamapela
35have adopted a click into their [0278]
230 270 24
dialect and a large infusion of
the ringing ñ, which seems to
have been for the purpose of
5preventing others ^ from understanding
them -


The fact of the complete
translation of the Bible at a
station 700 miles inland from
10the Cape naturally suggests the
question as to whether it is likely
to be permanently useful and
whether Christianity as planted by
modern missions is likely to
15retain its vitality without constant
supplies of foreign teaching -
It would certainly be no cause
for ^ congratulation if the Sichuana
Bible seemed at all likely to
20meet the fate of Elliot's Choctaw
version a specimen of which
may be seen in the library of
one of the American colleges
as Gods word in a language
25no living human tongue can
articulate or living mortal
understand - but a better destiny
seems in store for this for
the Sichuana language has
30been introduced into the new
country beyond Lake Ngami
there it is the court language
and will take you anywhere
through a district larger than
35France, and the Bechuana [0279]
XII. 231 271
in all probability possess the
imperishability which forms
so remarkable a feature in
5the entire African race



/
Daintree & Co. When converts are made
from heathenism by modern
missionaries it becomes
10an interesting question whether
their faith possesses the
elements of permanence
or is only an exotic too
tender for self propagation
15when the fostering care
of the foreign cultivators
is withdrawn - If habits
of self reliance are not both
sedulously cultivated and
20opportunities given for
the exercise of that virtue
the most promising converts
are apt to become like
spoiled children - In Madagascar
25a few Christians were
left with nothing but the
bible in their hands
and though exposed to
persecution and even
30death itself as the penalty
of adherence to their profession
they increased tenfold
in numbers and are if
possible more decided
35christi believers now than [0280]
232 272
they were when by an edict of
the queen of that island the
missionaries ceased their
5teaching -


In South Africa such
an experiment could not
be made for such a variety
of Christian sects have followed
10the footsteps of the London
Missionary Societys successful
career that converts of one
denomination if left to themselves
their own resources are eagerly
15adopted by another and are
thus more likely to become
spoiled children than trained
to the manly Christian virtues



20

Another element of weakness
in the part of the missionary
field is the fact of Missionary
Societies considering the Colony
a proper sphere for their peculiar
25operations - In addition to a
well organized and efficient
Dutch Reformed established
Church we have schools for
secular instruction maintained
30by Government in every
village of any extent in
the Colony, we have a number
of other sects as the Wesleyans
Episcopalians Moravians
35all piously labouring at the
same good work Now [0281]
233 273
it is deeply to be regretted that
so much honest zeal
should be so lavishly expended
5in a district whenever there
is so little scope for success
When we hear an agent
of one sect urging his
friends at home to aid
10him quickly to occupy some
unimportant nook because
if it is not speedily laid
hold of he will "not
have room for the sole of
15his foot" one cannot help
longing that both he and
his friends should direct
their noble aspirations to
the millions of true Heathen
20in the regions beyond - and
no longer continue to make
the extremity of the continent
as it were into a dam
of benevolence


25

I would earnestly
recommend all young
missionaries to go at once
on to the real heathen and
30never to be content with
what has been made ready
to his hands by men of greater
enterprise -          The idea of
making model christians
35of the young need not be [0282]
234 274
be entertained by any one who is
secretly convinced as most
men who know their own
5hearts are that he is not a
model Christian himself Our
own elevation has been the
work of ages and remembering
this we shall not indulge in
10overwrought expectations as
to what those who have inherited
the degradation of ages, in
our day may become -


And the principle might
15be adopted by missionary
Societies that one ordinary
missionaries lifetime of teaching
should be considered an
ample supply of foreign
20teaching for any tribe in a
thinly peopled country
A missionary is soon
known to be supported by
his friends at home - and
25though the salary is but a
bare subsistence to Africans
it seems an enormous sum
and being unable to appreciate
the motives by which he is
30actuated they consider them-
-selves entitled to various
services at his hands and
themselves defrauded if they
are not duly rendered - This
35feeling is all the stronger [0283]
235 275
when a young man instead
of going boldly to the real
heathen settles down in
5a comfortable house and
garden prepared by those
who into whose labours
he has entered - A remedy
for this might be found
10in appropriating the houses
and gardens raised by
[the] missionaries to their own
hands to their own families
It is ridiculous to call
15such places as Kuruman
for instance "Missionary
property"   This beautiful
station was made what
it is not by English money
20by by the sweat & toil
of fathers whose children
have notwithstanding
no place on earth they
can call a home - And
25in all probability it is
the strong built mission
premises are destined to
be the home of a Boer
and the stately stone
30church his cattle pen -


/ Protestant missionaries
of every denomination in
South Africa all agree in
one point that no mere
35profession of Christianity is [0284]
236 276
sufficient to entitle the converts
to the Christian name - They are all
anxious to place the bible in
5their hands and with ability
to read that there can be little
doubt as to the future - We
believe Christianity to be divine
and equal to all it has to
10perform - then let the good
seed be widely sown no
[and no] matter to what sect the converts
may belong the harvest will
be glorious - Nothing that
15I have said must be in-
-terpreted as indicative of
feelings inimical to any body
[of] Christians for I never as
a missionary felt myself
20to be either Presbyterian
Episcopalian or Independant
or called upon in any way
to love less one sect than
another - My earnest desire
25is that those who really have
the best interests of the heathen
at heart should go to them
and assuredly in Africa at
least selfdenying labours
30among real heathen will
be appreciated - Christians
have never yet dealt fairly
by the heathen and been
disappointed

25I am, Sechele, I am undone

5they assented -     They began on

with all their might and burned
the town with fire & scattered us
They killed sixty of my people
10and captured women and
children and men - And the
mother of Balering they also
took prisoner - they took
all the cattle and all the goods
15of the Bakwains - And the

20five and a cannon and

5

Very soon after A - .. W - Pretorius

10is justified by the Boers

15are the dead, who die in the Lord"

The report of this outrage
20on the Bakwains coupled
as it was with denunciations
against myself for having,
[as it was alleged, ^] ^ taught then to kill boers
produced such a panic in
25the country ^ that I could not engage
a single native to accompany
me to the North - During

no fewer than nine tribes
30had been attacked and large
numbers of children carried
off on each occasion - They
compel the tribes already
subjected to them to act as
35a shield to them by standing [0293]
245 15285
in front and repelling the attempt
of their countrymen to reach
the Boers, while the latter sit
5on their horses and coolly
fire over their heads - These
tribes being totally unprovided
with fire-arms - could never
break through the shield and
10never was a drop of Boerish
blood shed - The Bakwains
however having purchased
some guns killed twenty
eight Boers - and I recieved
15the credit of the difference
between the attacks of the nine
aforementioned tribes and
[that of] Kolobeng - Loud vows of

20my head and threats of instant
pursuit by a large party on

as these were coupled with
25the declaration that the English
Government had given over
the whole of the native tribes

30by preventing firearms
and ammunition from entering

/ When at last I found three

When we reached Motito

25Sechele on his way as he

she would ^ listen but the difficulty
is to get to her". "Well I shall
20reach her" expressed his final
determination - Others explained
the difficulties more fully but
[nothing could shake] his resolution was implacable
When he reached Bloemfontein
25he found the army of Sir

30engagement was not tried

obliged to return to his own
15country again - one thousand
miles distant in a straight
line without accomplishing
the object of his journey -


On his return
20he adopted a mode of punishment
he had seen in the colony viz
making criminals work
on the public roads - and he
has since I am informed
25b made himself the missionary
to his own people - He has
great intelligence, reads well
and is a fluent speaker
Great numbers of the tribes
30having under the Boers have
taken refuge under his sway
and he is now greater in
power than he was before
the attack on Kolobeng -

20the Desert from a point

XIII. 255 295
FrequentlyOccasionally during the
very dry seasons which
succeed our winter and
5preceede our rains a dry
[hot] ˄ wind blows over the
Desert from North to South
It feels somewhat as if
coming from an oven
10and seldom blows
longer at a time than three
days [↪ together] : It resembles in its
effects the Harmattan for
[of the North of
Africa for] ^ it co {a}mes loaded aboutat
15the time the missionaries
first settled in the country
30 {5} years ago loaded
with fine reddish coloured
sand - [↪ he sand no
longer appears
but it is so
devoid of
moisture that] And it causes the
20wood of the best seasoned
English boxes & furniture
to shrink so much that
every article not made
in the country becomes
25warped - The verls of
ramrods made in England
become loose and on
returning f {to} Europe fasten
again - This wind is so
30strongly electric that
a bunch of ˄ ostrich feathers held
in it [↪ a few seconds
against it] become as strongly
[⎰charged⎱] electrified as they would
do [↪ if attached to] in a powerful electrical
35machine, and clasp [0305]
256 296
the advancing hand as {wi}th
a ˄ short crackling sound as if the
experiment were performed
5in a chemical class room
On shewing this phenomenon
to a traveller ˄ once he begged the
feathers so earnestly that I
gave him the bunch without
10any explanation - On meeting
long afterwards I asked him
what explanations the philosophers
had given - "They had lost the
property by the time he got
15to the coast - !" When this
wind is blowing and even
at other times this peculiarly
[strong] electrical state of the atmosphere
causes the slightest move
20-ment of a native in his
Kaross to shew ofproduce a stream
of small sparks - The
first time I noticed this
[appearance ˄] was in the case of a chief
25travelling with me in my
waggon - Seeing parts of
[the fur of] his mantle ˄ which was exposed to
slight friction by the
movement of the waggon
30assume quite a luminous
appearance - I rubbed it
smartly with the hand &
found it ˄ readily gave ˄ out with the
greatest ease bright sparks
35and ˄ heard distinct cracks -

↪ numbered upwards of 4,000
Only a few of these breed at any time
in this country, I have often observed
5them and they never appeared on

no appearance of having paired
no chasing or playing together
10There are man several other birds
which continue in flocks and

15between the hot & cold cold & hot
seasons - cold acting some what in
the same way here as the general

Europe - Are these the migratory birds
20of Europe which return there to breed
and rear their young? [0307]

↪ Near the village there exists a cave named
Lepelole, It is an interesting evidence of the
former existence of a gushing fountain
5No one dared to enter into go near the Lohahen or the
the Lohaheng or cave for ^ x [^ x it was the common belief that] God was there, As we never

the th periods of our greatest exertions
10I projected an excursion hereinto the cave to see

who went in remained for ever -
said the old man and if the teacher is
so mad as to kill himself we shall not be
15to blame - The declaration of Sechele tha
he would follow where I led - produced
the greatest consternation - It is curious
that in all their pretended dreams or visions
of having seentheir god he has always a
20crooked leg; Like the Egyptian Thoth.

On the 31st Decr 1852 we reached
the town of Sechele called
from the part of the range
5on which it is situated
Litubaruba - ↪ I never
[-] saw the Bakwains looking
so haggard and lean
as now - Most of the
10cattle had been swept away
together with about 80
fine draught oxen and
much provision left [↪ in charge]
by two officers Captains
15Codrington and Webb to
[serve ˄] for their return journey
South - They {se} ^ officers found the
skeletons of the Bakwains
where they expected to find
20their goods - All the corn,
clothing, and furniture
of the people had been
consumed in the flames
which the Boers had
25forced the subject tribes
to apply [↪ to the town
during the fight] to the So they were
now literally starving -


/ Sechele had given orders
to his people not to
30commit any act of
revenge pending his
visit to the queen ˄ of England - but
some of the young men
ventured to go to a party
35of Boers returning from [0310]
259 5 299
hunting and as the Boers
became terrified and
ran off they brought
5their waggon to Litubaruba
This seems to have given
the main body an idea
that he {^} [the Bakwains] meant to begin
a guerilla war upon
10them - This Caffre war
was however only in
embryo and not near
that stage of [development

15after the Boers have
unwisely inherited, when
the native finds the hide
and seed seek system

20Boers in alarm sent
to ask for peace! I being
present heard the condition
"Sechele's children must
be given up" - I never
25saw men so completely
and unconsciously in
a trap as these four Boers
were - Strong parties of
armed Bakwains occupied
30every pass in the hills &
gorges around and had
they not promised much
more than they intended
or did perform that sunday
35would have been their

Mr Peit Scholz the commandant

    See back of this page [0312]
7+
The Bechuanas are universally much
attached to children - A little child toddling
near a party of men eating is sure
5to get a handful of the food - This
love of children may depend inin a great
partmeasure on the patriarchal system under which
they dwell - Every little stranger is an
increase of value influence to the whole community
10and is duly reported to the chief - boys
being more esteemed welcome than girls - The
parents take the name of the child & often address
their children as Ma or Ra - (mother & father)
Our eldest boy being named Robert Mrs
15L - was after his birth always addressed
as Marobert - instead of Mary her maiden
name -


I have examined several cases in
which a grandmother has taken upon herself
20to suckle a grandchild - Masina of Kuruman
had no children after the birth of her ^ daughter Sina
and had no milk after Sina was weaned
which usually is deferred till the child is
two or three years old - Sina married
25when she was 17 or 18 and had twins
Masina ^ after at least 15 years interval took possession of one of
them applied it to her breast and milk
followed so that she was able to nursed
the child ^ Entirely - ⎰On examination it seemed like [omit]
30 other human milk only perhaps a little⎱
more bluish than ordinary - She was at
this time at least 40 years of age -
I have witnessed several other cases
analogous to this - A grandmother left
35at home with a young child ^ frequently applies
it to her own shrivelled breast ^
                                                See back of next page [0313]
261 301
from experience that adult
captives may as well be
left where they are but {for}
5escape is so easy in
wild country that no
fugitive slave law can

therefore adopt the system
10of seizing the youngest
children that these may
forget their parents and
remain in perpetual bondage
I have seen mere infants
15in their houses repeatedly -

The diseases known
among the Bakwains
20are remarkably few -
There is no consumption, nor
scrofula and insanity and
hydrocephalus are rare -
Cancer and cholera are
25quite unknown - Smallpox
and measles came through
the country about twenty
years ago but t and com-
mitted great ravages
30but though the former was
[has since broken out ^] on the coast repeatedly
[neither disease has] they never travelled inland
since - For small pox
[the natives] they employed in some
35parts inoculation with

263 303
droppings of a bull - In
other parts they employed
the matter of the small
5pox itself and in one
village they seem to have
selected a virulent case
for the matter used in
the operation for nearly
10all the village was
swept off by the disease
in a malignant confluent
form - Where the idea
came from I cannot
15concieve - It was practised
by the Bakwains at a time
when they had no intercourse
direct or indirect with
the Southern missionaries - [↪ They all adopt

20

Syphilis is unknown
also - I have seen cases
in which it had been
imparted and appeared in
the secondary form ^ but it died
25out without the aid of
medicine - And the Bang
-waketze who got the
mildest form of it from
a tribe of Damaras near
30the West Coast lost it
when they came into their
own land South West
of Kolobeng - It seems
incapable of permanence
35in any form in persons [0317]
264 10304
of pure African blood anywhere
in the centre of the country,
In persons of mixed
5blood it is otherwise and
the virulence of the secondary
symptoms seemed to be
in all the cases that came
under my care - in exact
10proportion to the greater
or less amount of European
blood in the patient -
Among the Corannas and
Griquas of mixed breed
15it produces the same
ravages as in Europe -
Among half blood Portuguese
it is equally frightful
in its inroads on the
20system but in the pure
Negro of the central parts
it is quite incapable of
permanence - Among the
Barotse I found a disease
25called Manassah which
closely resembles ^ that of the "foeda
mulier", of history -

15or days before their

20concealed I had to rest

Frequently the Bakwains
burned their dead in
the huts where they died
25for fear lest the witches

their friends and use
some parts of the body

30Scarcely did the is the
breath out of the body

patient is hurried away

[while I was there,] this hasty burial led to

↪ The doctors cup on the
10temples and apply ↪ the
pungent smoke [↪ of certain roots] ⎰to the eyes⎱

patient at the same time
taking strong draughts of
15it up his nostrils - We
found the solution of nitrate
of silver * [* 2 or 3 grams
to the ounce
of rain water] answer
the same end so much
more effectually that
20every morning crowds
numbers ^ of patients crowded round
our house for the collyrium
It is a good preventative
of an acute attack
25when poured in to the eyes
as soon as the pain
begins and might prove
valuable for travellers
The cupping glass is performed
30by the horn of a goat or
antelope having a smalllittle
hole pierced in the small

small piece of wax is
35attached and a temporary
hole made through it to [0321]
268 308
in the horn - When the air is
well withdrawn by keeping
the touching the orifice at
5every inspiration with the
point of the tongue - The
wax is at last bittenpressed with
the teeth and the orifice ob-
literated [closed up] so as to leave a
10vacuum for the blood
to flow from the already
scarified parts - The edges of
[the horn] applied to the surface are
wetted and cupping is well
15performed though the doctor
occasionally by separating
the fibrine from the blood
in the basin of water by

20pretends that he has extracted
something more than blood
He can then explain the
rationale of the cure by his
own art and the ocular
25demonstration given is well
appreciated -


Those doctors who have
[inherited ↪ ] the {is} profession as an heirloom
[from their fathers & grandfathers ^] generally possess some
30valuable knowledge the
result of long and close
observation - but if a man
cannot say the medical art
is in his family he may
35be considered a quack. With [0322]
269 309
the others I always remained

x Aside, any explanation was

10 [something more] more reasonable with cordial

15 [asked for &] accepted by all - And we
always found medical knowledge

20for their welfare - We cannot
accuse them of ingratitude
[^ in fact We shall] We remember the kindness of
the Bakwains to us as long
as we live -

270 310
The surgical knowledge of
the native doctors is rather
at a low ebb - No one ever
5attempted to remove a tumour
except by external applications
Those with which they are
chiefly troubled are fatty &
fibrous tumours - and as
10they all have the vis medicatrix
naturae in remarkable
activity I safely removed
an immense number
In illustration of their want
15of surgical knowledge it
may be mentioned that
a man having a tumour
as large as a childs head
[-] which being situated on
20the nape of his neck
prevented himhis walking
straight - applied to his chief
to get some famous strange
doctor from the East coast
25to cure him - They attempted
to dissolve it by kindling
[on it] a little fire ^ on it made of a few
[small] little pieces of medicinal
roots - When I removed it
30 [for him and] he always walked with his
head much more erect
than he needed to do ever
afterwards - Both men &
women submit to an
35operation without wincing
or any of that shouting [0324]
271 311
which caused young students
to faint in the operating
theatre before the introduction
5of chloroform - - The women
pride themselves on their
ability to bear pain - A
mother will address her child
[little girl] from whose foot a thorn
10is to be extracted by - "Now
Ma you are a woman - A
woman does not cry" - A
man too scorns to shed tears
When we were passing one of
15the deep wells in the Kalahari
a boy the only son of an
aged father had been drowned
in it while playing on
its brink - When all hope
20was gone ^ the father he uttered an
exceedingly great & bitter cry
It was sorrow without
hope, This was the only
instance I ever met with
25of a man weeping in
this country -

and all the ointments of all

after reserved myself for the
difficult cases only and
had the satisfaction of often
20conferring great benefits
on poor women in their

[creatures] are often leftplaced in a little hut

/ My knowledge of
obstetrics procured for me
10a great fame in a line
toin which I could lay no
claim ^ to merit - A woman came
from the a distance of 100 miles
for relief in a complaint
15which seemed to have
baffled the native doctors
a complete cure was the
result - Soon after she
returned to her husband she
20concieved and bore a son
Her husband having
previously reproached her
for being barren she sent
me a handsome present
25and proclaimed all over
the country that I possessed
thea medicine for the cure
of sterility - The consequence
was ^ that I was pestered with
30applications from husbands
and wives all over the
country - Some came upwards
of 200 miles to purchase
the great boon and it was
35in vain ^ for me to explain ^ that I could
only cure the disease of [0327]
274 20 {314}
the other case - The more I
denied they higher their offers
became - They would give
5any money for the "child
medicine" and it was really
heart rending to hear the
earnest entreaty and see
the tearful eye which spoke
10the intense desire - "I am getting
old, you see gray hairs here
and there on my head, and
I have no child, you know
how Bechuana husbands
15cast their old wives away
What can I do, I have no
child to bring water to me
when I am sick" &c -

/ The whole of the country
adjacent to the Desert from
Kuruman to Kolobeng
or Litubaruba and beyond
up to the Latitude of
25Lake Ngami is remarkable
for its great salubrity of
climate - Not only the natives
but Europeans whose
constitutions have been im-
30-paired by an Indian climate
find the tract of country
indicated not subject both healthy
[and] but restorative - The health
and longevity of the missionaries [0328]
275 315
has {ve} been always fair, though
mission work is not
very conducive to either
5elsewhere - Cases have
been known in which
patients have come from
the coast with a complaints
[closely] ^ simulatingresembling if ^ it they were not
10actually ^ those of consumption, {;}
and they have recovered
by the influence of the
climate alone - One of these
a woman I examined
15and found ovarian
tumour, as if the tuberculous
matter had had been
removed from the lungs
& deposited [↪ in another organ] there - She
20is still aliveng while had
she with that same disease
remained near the coast
it would speedily ^ have been as
fatal to her as it is to
25the Hottentots - It must
always bee borne in mind
that the climate near the
coast from which we
recieved sosuch very favourable
30reports of the health of the
British troops is actually
inferior to that of any
part not subjected to
the influence of sea air
35I have never seen the [0329]
276 316
the beneficial effects of the

10more extensively known ^
[in England ^] N No one who has

to remember thewith pleasure
15of the wild healthful gipsey

Mr Oswel declares this

and but for the impossibility

25the medical world and

to recommend the borders
30of the Kalahari desert
as admirably suited for
all patients having
pulmonary complaints
It is the complete antipodes
35to our cold damp English [0330]
277 317
climate - The winter is perfectly
dry - and as not a drop of
rain falls during that
5period - viz from the beginning
of May to the end of August
damp and cold are never
combined - However hot
the day was {may} have been
10at Kolobeng and the thermometer
sometimes rose previous
to a fall of rain up to 96°
in the coolest part of our
house yet it never has
15that steamy feeling nor
those debilitating effects
so well known in India
In the evenings the air
becomes deliciously cool
20and a pleasant refreshing
night follows the hottest
day -   The greatest heat
ever felt is not so oppressive
as it is when there is much
25humidity in the air and
the great evaporation
consequent on a fall of
rain makes the raining
season the most agreable
30for travelling - Nothing can
exceed the delicious balmy
feeling of the evenings &
mornings aft {du}ring the whole
year - You can wish for
35⎰neither⎱ an increase ↪ of
cold nor heat - It is perfect [0331]
278 24 {318}
and you can sit out at night till
[midnight ^] twelve ^ without ever thinking
of colds or Rheumatism - And
5 [you] one may sleep out at night
looking up to the moon till
you fall asleep without
a thought or sign of moon
blindness - Indeed during many
10months there is scarcely any
dew -


Having remained five days
with the wretched Bakwains
seeing the effects of war of which
15a very inadequate idea can
ever be formed by those who
have not been eye witnesses
of its miseries - I {we} prepared to
depart - Several dogs in better
20condition by far than any of
the people had taken up their
residence at the water - No one
would own them - they had
remained, and returning coming ^
25 [↪ on the trail of
25the people long
25after their departure
25from the scene
25of conflict it was
25plain] they "Held oer the dead their carnival"
[                ]

Hence the disgust with which
they were viewed


In proceeding from
30Khopong along the ancient
river bed which forms the
pathway to Boatlanama
we found another species
of cactus - Thus making [0332]
XIV - 319
being the third I have seen
in the country, viz, - one
73 at a part of the Colony called
5f {a}fter it the "Koup," with a
bright red flower- {;} one at

is edible is liver coloured,
and the present ^ one whose flower
10is unknown- {;} ^ That the plant
is uncommon may be
inferred from the fact
that the Bakwains find

15recognizing a plant again
after having once seen it,
T {t}hey believe it has the power
of changing its locality -

/ Bristow On the 21st January we reached we
reached the wells of Boatlanama
and found them for the first
time empty - Lopepe which
I had formerly seen a running
25stream was and a from a large
[reedy] pool was also dry - The hot
salt spring of Serinane East of
Lopepe was {being} undrinkable
we pushed on to Mashue
30 [for] with its delicious waters
In travelling through this country
the olfactory organ nerves
are frequently excited by
a strong disagreeable odour
35This is caused by ↪ a large jet black an ant [0333]
320
named "Leshonya" - It is quite an
nearly an inch in length and
74 emits thisa pungent smell
5when alarmed in the same
manner as is practised
by the skunk and polecat ^ dog
The scent must be as volatile
as ether for on irritating the
10insect with a stick 6six feet long
the It is instantly perceptible


Occasionally we lighted
upon land tortoises which
[↪ with their inlaid
eggs] make a very agreeable dish
15We saw many of their trails
leading to the salt fountain
they and ^ they must seem to have come great
distances for this health giving
article -     In lieu thereof they
20often devour wood ashes
It is wonderful to see how
this reptile holds its place in
the country - It hol {When} When seen it
never escapes - The young
25are taken for the sake of
their shells to be made into
boxes which filled with
sweet smelling roots the
women hang around their
30persons - When older it is
used as food and the
shell converted into a
[    ] rude basin to hold
food or water - It owes its
35continuance neither to speed [0334]
321
nor cunning - Its colour yellow
75 and dark brown is well adapted
by its similarity to the surrounding
5grass & brushwood to render
it indistinguishable and though
it makes an awkward attempt
to run on the approach of man
its trust is in its bony covering
10from which even the
teeth, of a hyaena glance off
foiled - When this long lived
cl creature is about to deposit
her eggs she lets herself into the
15ground by throwing the earth
up round her shell untill
only the top is visible - There
covering up the eggs she
leaves them covered up untill
20the rains begin to fall and
Robinson the fresh herbage [appears -
The young ones then come
out - their shells still quite soft
and unattended by their dams
25begin the world for themselves
Their food is tender grass and
a plant named Thotona - and
they frequently resort to ashes
& parts containing efflorescence
30of the nitrates for the salts these contain


Enquiries among the
Bushmen and Bakalahari [↪ who are intimately
acquainted with
the habits of
the game - ]
lead to the belief that many
diseases prevail among
35wild animals - I have seen [0335]
322
the kokong or gnu, Kāma
76 or hartebeest,     The Tsessebe
[↪ Kukama] and even the giraffe so mangy
5as to be uneatable even by the
natives, Reference has already
been made to the peripneumonia
which cuts off horses Tolos or
Khoodoos, and ^ that great numbers,
10 [also,] of Zebras are found ^ dead with the
a masses of foam at the nostrils
exactly as occurs in the ^ common "horse
sickness" - The production
of the malignant carbuncle
15called Kuatsi or selonda is {by}
[the flesh when
eaten is] ^ another proof of the disease ↪ of the tame & wild
being identical -


I once found a buffalo
blind from ophthalmia standing
20by the fountain Otse and when
he attempted to run he lifted
up his feet in the peculiar
manner blind animals do,
The Rhinoceros has often
25X worms on the conjunctiva
of his eyes but these are
not the cause of his {the} dimness
of vision which will make
him charge past a man
30who has wounded him
if he stands perfectly still,
in the belief that his enemy
is a tree -     It probably arises
from the horn being in the
35line of vision for the variety [0336]
5 {323}
77 named Kuabaōba which has
a straight horn directed down-
[-wards ^] away from that line has much
5more acute eyesight & is much [more wary]


All the wild animals are subject
to intestinal worms besides,
I have observed bunches of a
tapelike worm - thread and
10short worms of enlarged size
in the Rhinoceros - The zebras
[& Elephants] are seldom without them, and
a thread worm may often be
seen under the peritoneum
15of these animals - Short red
larvae which convey a stinging
sensation to the hand are
seen clustering round the orifice
of the windpipe (trachea) of this animal
20at the back of the throat - others
are seen in the frontal sinus
of antelopes and curious
flat leechlike worms with
black eyes are found in
25the stomachs of Lechés
↪ insert a         X
paragraph at
top of 7
[                ]


The carnivori too become
diseased and mangy - Lions
30become lean and perish
miserably by reason of the
decay of the teeth - When he
[a Lion ^] becomes too old to catch
game he frequently takes to [0337]
324
to killing goats in the villages
78 A woman or child happening
to go out ^ at night falls a prey too - And
5as this is his only source
of subsistence now, he continues
at it, From this circumstances
has arisen the idea that the
lion when he has once tasted
10human blood flesh loves it
better than any other - Men=
=eaters are invariably old -
and when he overcomes
his fear of man so far as
15to come to villages for
goats the people remark
"his teeth are worn out
he will soon kill men" They
at once acknowledge the the
20necessity [↪ of forestalling
20this] of and turning out to
kill him - When living far
[away] apart from population or
when as is the case in some

25dread of the Bushmen and
Bakalahari ^ so soon as either disease
or old age overtakes him
he begins to catch mice &
other small rodents and even
30to eat grass - the natives observing
undigested ^ vegetable matter in his
[or in sickness] droppings follow up his
trail in the certainty of finding
him scarcely able to move
35under some tree - (The grass
may have been eaten as medicine
as is observed in dogs)

Where game is abundant
there you may expect lions in proportionately large
numbers - They are never seen in herds but six or
35eight, probably one family, occasionally hunt together
One is in much more danger of being run over
in walking the street of London than he is of

          engaged in hunting the animal

[0357]

194


When we reached the Bamangwato, the
chief Sekomi was particularly friendly, -
collected all his people to the ^ religious services ^ we held,
5and explained his reasons for compelling
some Englishmen to pay him a horse - "They
would not sell him any powder, though
they had plenty; so he compelled them to give it
^ & the horse for nothing" - He would not deny the extortion
10to me; that would be "boherehere," "swindling,"
He thus thought extortion better than swindling(.)
I could not detect any more difference in
the morality of the two, transactions than in the dangerousness
of apoplexy & Coup de Soleil, but Sekomi's
15ideas of things are honesty are the
lowest I have met with in any
Bechuana chief, and this instance
is mentioned as the only approach to
payment for leave to passpass that I have
20met with in the South(.) - In all other
cases the difficulty has been to get
a chief to give a {us} man to shew the
way, - and the payment has been for such
a guide (-) and Englishmen have always
25very properly avoided giving that idea
to the native mind which we shall
hereafter find ^ proved troublesome, that payment
ought to be made for passage through
a country


30

In this town I was once a spectator
Qu ⎰of the second part of the ceremony of the
circumcision ^ (Boguera) or ci - called "Sechu(.)" Just at the
dawn of day a row of boys of ^ nearly fourteen
Qu years of age ^ nearly stood ^ naked in the Kotla, each
35having a pair of sandals as a shield on⎱ [0358]
91 337 19
his hands(.) - Facing them stood the men of
the town in a similar state of nudity - all
armed with long thin wands, of a tough
5strong supple bush called Moretloa, and
engaged in a dance named "Koha", in which
questions are put to the boys; as, "will you
gaurdguard the chief well?" "Will you herd
the cattle well?" - and while the latter give
10an affirmative response, one after the
and another of the men rushes forward
to them and ^ Each aims a full weight blow at
the boy's back ^ of one of the boys; he, shielding himself with
the sandals above his head, causes the
15supple wand to descend & bend in to his
back, and every stroke inflicted thus
causes the blood to squirt out of a
wound a foot or eighteen inches
long(.) - At the end of the dance the boys'
20backs are seamed with wounds & weals,
that ^ the scars of which remain through life(.) This is intended
to harden the young soldiers, and prepare
them for the rank of men(.) - They may
there after marry - this ceremony, and after
25killing a Rhinoceros, ^ they may marry a wife(.)
In the "Koha" the same respect is shewn
to age as in many other of their customs -
A younger man rushing from the ranks
to exercise his wand on the backs of
30the youths may be himself the object
of chastisement by the older, and on
the occasion referred to Sekomi himself
recieved a handsomesevere cut on the leg
from one of his grey-haired people(.)
35On my joking with some of the young
men on their want of courage notwith-
                                                        standing [0359]
all the beatings of which they bore marks,
and hinting that our soldiers were brave
without suffering so much, one rose up
and said, "Ask him if, when he and I were
5compelled by a lion to stop & make a fire,
if I did not lie down and sleep as well as
himself(.)" In other parts a challenge to try
a race would have been given, and
you willmay frequently see grown men
10adopting that means of testing
superiority, like so many children -


The Sechu is practised by
Qu: three tribes only - ↪ Boguera (Circumcision) is
observed by all the Bechuanas and
15Caffres, but not by the negro tribes
beyond 20˚ South (-) It is named
"Boguera", and is a civil rather than
a religious rite (-) All the boys of the an
age between 10 and 14 or 15 are selected
20 [to] be the companions for life of one of
the sons of the chief - They are taken
out to some retired spot in the forest,
and huts ^ are erected for their accommodation
The old men go out and teach them
25to dance, initiating them at the same
time in all the mysteries of African
politics & government (-) Each one
is expected to compose an oration
in praise of himself, called a "leina" or
30name, - and to be able to repeat it with
sufficient elo fluency - A good deal
of beating is required to bring them
up to the required excellency in differen
matters, so ^ that when they return from
35          (Turn over three leaves for
                      continuation of this subject) [0360]
338 20
- close seclusion in which they
92 are kept, they have generally
a number of scars to shew
5on their backs - These bands
or regiements, named Mepato,
recieved a name a particular
appellation; as, the Matsatsi =
The suns; the Mabusa =
10the rulers - equivalent to our
Coldstreams or Enniskillens;
and they [↪ though living
at different
parts of the
town, turn out
at the call, and] act under the chief's
son as ^ their commander - They
recognize a sort of
15equality & partial communism
even afterwards, [↪ and address
each other by
the endearing
name title of Molekane,
or comrade (-)
In cases of
offence against
their maxims↪ ,
as eating alone
when any of
their comrades
are within call,
or in cases of
cowardice or
dereliction of
duty, they may] May
^ strike each other, and those
of a younger mo-pato,
but never anyone of
20any older one {band}; and
when three or four mepato
have been made, the oldest
no longer takes the field
in time of war but remains
25as a gauuard over the women
and children (-) When a fugitive
comes to a tribe, he is directed
to the Mopato analogous
to that to which in his own
30tribe he belongs, and does
duty as a member (-) Age is
reckoned by the number of
the mepato they have seen
pass through the formulas
35of admission (-) The oldest [0361]
93 339
individual I ever met boasted
he had seen eleven sets of
Qu ⎰ boys submit to the [↪ Boguera (circumcision),] circumcision⎱
5i-e he must have been fifty
[forty] when he saw the fifth (-) It is
an ingenious plan for fixing
attaching the members of
the tribe to the chief's family,
10and ^ for imparting a discipline
which renders the tribe easy
of command (-) On their
return to the town, a prize is
given to the lad who can
15run fastest, the article being
placed where all may see
the winner run up to
snatch it - They are then
considered men [↪ (banona - viri)] , and can
20sit among the elders in the
Kotla (-) Formerly they were
only basimane pueri - boys(.)
The first missionaries
set their faces against
25the Boguera on account
of its connection with
heathenism, and the fact
that they youth learned
much evil, and become
30disobedient to their parents
(-) From the general success
of these men, it is perhaps
better that younger missionaries
should tread in their footsteps,
35for so much evil may ˄

The Bamangwato hills are
part of the range called Bakaa
(Qu. What tribe?
Bakaa of course) The latter tribe ^ (Bakaa) however removed
5to Kolobeng and are now
joined to that of Sechele
96 They {The} range stands almost 700
or 800 feet above the plains
and areis composed of great
10masses of black basalt
and areIt is probably ^ part of the youngestlatest
[series of] volcanic rocks in South

they havethese hills have of a curious fungoid
15or cup shaped hollows

form of this formation
⎰ X Qu: The tops of the columns are
20quite distinct, of the hexagonal

In many parts the lava

rent & split in every
30direction but no soil ^ is yet

When ^ we were sitting in the evenings
after a hot day it iswas quite
common to hear these
35masses of basalt split [0365]
5 {343}
split and fall among each
other with the peculiar ringing
sounds which makes
5people believe that this rock
contains much iron - Several
97 large masses in splitting
thus by the cold acting suddenly
on parts expanded by
10the heat of the day have
slipped down the sides of
the hills and impinging
against each other
formed cavities in which
15the Bakaa took refuge
against their enemies
The numerous chinks and
cranies left by these huge frag-
ments made it quite impossible
20for their enemies to smoke
them out as was done by

Mankopane -


This mass of basalt about
25six miles long has tilted
Qu say up the rocks, on both the

10If you look North from

[0368]

346
In no part of this country could
European grain be cultivated
without irrigation - The natives
5all cultivate the Dourrha or
100 Caffre Sorghum - maize - pumpkins
melons cucumbers and different
kinds of beans - and they are
entirely dependant for the
10growth of these on rains
Their instrument of culture is
the hoe and the chief labour
falls on the female portion
of the community - In this
15respect the Bechuanas closely
resemble the Caffres - The
men engage in hunting -
they milk the cows and have
the entire controul of the cattle
20They prepare the skins - and
make the clothing and
in some respects resemble
a nation of tailors

25 generally have heard his praises

a chief so much that he

January 28th Passing on to Letloche, about
twenty miles beyond the Bamangwato,
we found a fine supply of water,
This is an interesting fact in
that country; - The first question
10we ask of passers by is "have
you had water?" - The first
enquiry a native puts to
a fellow countryman is
"Where is the rain" and, though
15they are by no means an
untruthful nation the answer
generally is "I don't know
there is none, - we are
killed with hunger and
20by the sun" - If news areis
asked for, they commence
with there areis "no news
I heard some lies only,"
x
Qu furthest and then tell all they know
25This spot was - Mr Mr - Gordon
Cummings x farthest station
North; - Our house at
Kolobeng having been quite [0370]
10 {348}
in the hunting country - Rhinoceros
and buffaloes having several
times rushed past and enabled
5 [I was able] me to shoot the latter from
our own door: - We were
favoured by visits from this
102 famous hunter during
each of the five years of his
10warfare with wild animals
Many English gentlemen following
the same pursuits paid
equally with him their guides
and assistants so punct-
15ually that in furnishing
[making arrangements] guides for them we had
to be careful that four
[did] should not go where
two only were wanted
20They knew so well that
an Englishman would
pay them that they depended
implicitly on theirhis words
of honour, and would
25not only ^ would they go and hunt
for five or six months
in the North, going through
[Enduring] all the hardships of that
trying mode of life with
30little else but meat of
game to subsist on, - but
they willingly went 700
or 800 miles to the Grahams
town ^ [receivingreceiving] for wages comprized
35 [only] in a musket, worth 15/ [0371]
349
No one ever decieved them
except one man, and as I
believed ^ that he was afflicted with
5a slight degree of the insanity
103 of greediness I upheld the
honour of the English
name by paying his debts
to them - As the guides
10of Mr Cumming were
furnished by me through my
influence and usually got
some strict charges as to
their behaviour before parting
15they, looking upon me in
the light of a father, always
came to givinggive me an account
of their service, - andand told
us most of those hunting adventur
20which have since been
given to the world before we
had the pleasure of hearing
our friend relate them
himself by our ^ own fire side
25I had thus a tolerably good
opportunity of testing their
value, and I have no
hesitation that in saying
that for those who love that
30sort of thing Mr Cumming's
book conveys a pretty
truthful id idea of South

350

5large game there in the country

15spring - Where fire arms

[is to be found ^] in numbers much greater
20than Mr Cumming ever saw -
The Tsetse is however an
insuperable barrier to hunting
with horses there, and Europeans
can do nothing on foot - {;} The
25step of the elephant inwhen charging
back on the hunter, though
apparently not quick is so
long that the pace equals
the speed of a good horse
30at a canter; - A young
sportsman no matter how
great in ^ among pheasants, foxes
and hounds of braving
fever would do well to
35pause before resolving [0373]
351
brave fever for the excitement
of standing risking such a
terrific charge;   The scream,
5or trumpeting, of this enormous
105 brute when infuriated is
more like ^ what the shriek of a French
steam whistle ^ would sound to a man standing
on the dangerous part of
10a railroad than any other
earthly sound - A horse
unused to it will sometimes
stand shivering instead of
taking his rider out of
15danger - OrIt has happened
often ^ that the poor animals legs
will do their duty so badly,
[that] he may fall and expose
[his] the rider to be trodden into
20mummy, or losing his presence
of mind, the rider may
dash under a tree and
crack his cranium onagainst a
branch - As one charge
25has made embryo Nimrods
bid a final adieu to the chase
incipient Gordon Cummings
might try their nerves by
standing on the railways till the
30 [Engines] tenders were within 150 yards
of them, - Hunting elephants

Robinson Some wells east beyond Kann
Letloche at a spot named Kanne
we found them carefully hedged
5round by the people of a
106 Bakalahari village situated
near them - We have then 90 60
miles of country without water
& very distressing for the oxen
10as it is generally deep soft
sand - There is one sucking
place, around which was
congregated great numbers
of bushwomen with their
15eggshells and reeds - Mathuluane
now contained no water
and Motlatsa only a litsmall supply
so we sent the oxen across
the country to the deep well
20Nkauane and half were lost
in the way - When found at
last they had been five whole
days without water - Very
large numbers of elands were
25were met with - here as usual
though they seldom can get
a sip of ^ drink water - Many of
the plains here have large
expanses of grass without
30trees but you seldom ever
see a treeless horizon -
The ostrich is generally seen
quietly feeding on some
spot, where, no one can
35approach him without [0375]
15 {353}
being detected by his wary eye -
As the waggon moves along
far to the windward he thinks
5it is intending to circumvent
107 him so he rushes up a mile
or so from the leeward and
so near to the front oxen
[that] one sometimes gets a shot
10at the silly bird - When he
begins to run all the game
in sight follow his example
I have seen his folly taken
advantage of by when he was
15quietly feeding in a valley
open at both ends - A
number of men would
commence running as
if to close one: cut off his
20retreat from the end f {t}hrough
which the wind blew and
although he had the whole
country to the Cape ^ for hundreds of miles before him
by going to the other end, on he
25madly rushed to get past the
men and ^ so got speared [↪ He never swerves
from the course
he once adopts
but only increases
his speed]

The ostrich begins to lay

25fixed on a spot for a nest ^ [which is only a

25deep in the sand

The egg is possessed of
very great vital power
One kept in a room during

30 [about] of 60° when broken was
